1.3.6: Integration by Parts The technique known (awkwardly) as integration by parts exploits the product rule for derivatives: d   d   x ( f g ) = f ( d   g d   x ) + g ( d   f d   x ) \dv{}{x} (fg) = f \left( \dv{g}{x} \right) + g \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) d x d ​ ( f g ) = f ( d x d g ​ ) + g ( d x d f ​ ) Integrating both sides, and invoking the fundamental theorem, ∫ a b d   d   x ( f g ) d x = f g ∣ a b = ∫ a b f ( d   g d   x ) d x + ∫ a b g ( d   f d   x ) d x \int_a ^b \dv{}{x} (fg) \dd x = \left. fg \right| ^b _a = \int _a ^b f \left( \dv{g}{x} \right) \dd x + \int_a ^b g \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) \dd x ∫ a b ​ d x d ​ ( f g ) d x = f g ∣ a b ​ = ∫ a b ​ f ( d x d g ​ ) d x + ∫ a b ​ g ( d x d f ​ ) d x or ∫ a b f ( d   g d   x ) d x = − ∫ a b ( d   f d   x ) d x + f g ∣ a b (1.58) \int_a ^b f \left( \dv{g}{x} \right) \dd x = - \int_a ^b \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) \dd x + \left. fg \right| ^b _a \tagl{1.58} ∫ a b ​ f ( d x d g ​ ) d x = − ∫ a b ​ ( d x d f ​ ) d x + f g ∣ a b ​ ( 1 . 5 8 ) That's "integration by parts." It applies to the situation in which you are called upon to integrate the product of one function (f) and the derivative of another (g); it says you can transfer the derivative from g to f, at the cost of a minus sign and a boundary term. Example 1.12 Evaluate the integral ``` \int _0 ^\infty x e^{-x} \dd x Solution The exponential can be expressed as a derivative: e − x = d   d   x ( − e − x ) e^{-x} = \dv{}{x} \left( - e^{-x} \right) e − x = d x d ​ ( − e − x ) in this case, then, f ( x ) = x f(x) = x f ( x ) = x , g ( x ) = − e − x g(x) = - e^{-x} g ( x ) = − e − x , and d f / d x = 1 df /dx = 1 d f / d x = 1 , so ∫ 0 ∞ x e − x d x = ∫ 0 ∞ e − x d x − x e − x ∣ 0 ∞ = − e − x ∣ 0 ∞ = 1 \int_0 ^\infty x e^{-x} \dd x = \int _0 ^{\infty} e^{-x} \dd x - \left. x e^{-x} \right| _{0} ^{\infty} = - \left. e^{-x} \right| _0 ^{\infty} = 1 ∫ 0 ∞ ​ x e − x d x = ∫ 0 ∞ ​ e − x d x − x e − x ∣ ∣ ∣ ​ 0 ∞ ​ = − e − x ∣ ∣ ∣ ​ 0 ∞ ​ = 1 We can exploit the product rules of vector calculus, together with the appropriate fundamental theorems, in exactly the same way. For example, integrating ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) = f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) + A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) \div (f\vec{A}) = f(\div \vec{A}) + \vec{A} \cdot (\grad f) ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) = f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) + A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) over a volume, and invoking the divergence theorem, yileds ∫ ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) d τ = ∫ f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ + ∫ A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ ∮ f A ⋅ d a \int \div (f \vec{A}) \dd \tau = \int f(\div \vec{A}) \dd \tau + \int \vec{A} \cdot (\grad f) \dd \tau \ \oint f \vec{A} \cdot \dd \vec{a} ∫ ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) d τ = ∫ f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ + ∫ A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ ∮ f A ⋅ d a or ∫ V f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ = − ∫ V A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ + ∮ S f A ⋅ d a (1.59) \int _V f(\div \vec{A}) \dd \tau = - \int _V \vec{A} \cdot (\grad f) \dd \tau + \oint _S f \vec{A} \cdot \dd \vec{a} \tagl{1.59} ∫ V ​ f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ = − ∫ V ​ A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ + ∮ S ​ f A ⋅ d a ( 1 . 5 9 ) Here again the integrand is the product of one function (f) and the derivative (in this case the divergence) of another ( A ), and integration by parts licenses us to transfer the derivative from A to f (where it becomes a gradient), at the cost of a minus sign and a boundary term (in this case a surface integral). In practice, this turns out to be one of the most useful tools at our disposal in vector calculus. Though you might wonder how often you're really likely to encounter an integral involving the product of one function and the derivative of another, the answer is surprisingly often .
docs.title: 1.3 - Integral Calculus

docs.text: In electrodynamics, we encounter several different kinds of integrals, among which the most important are line (or path) integrals , surface integrals , and volume integrals .
docs.title: 1.3.1: Line, Surface, and Volume Integrals

docs.text: A line integral is an expression of the form ∫ a b v ⋅ d l (1.48) \int_a ^b \vec{v} \cdot \dd{\vec{l}} \tagl{1.48} ∫ a b ​ v ⋅ d l ( 1 . 4 8 ) where v is a vector function, d l \dd \vec{l} d l is the infinitesimal displacement vector and the integral is to be carried out along a prescribed path P from point a to point b . If the path in question forms a closed loop (that is, if b = a \vec{b} = \vec{a} b = a , then put a circle on the integral sign: ∮ v ⋅ d l (1.49) \oint \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{l} \tagl{1.49} ∮ v ⋅ d l ( 1 . 4 9 ) At each point on the path, we take the dot product of v (evaluated at that point) with the displacement to the next point on the pat. To a physicist, the most familiar example of a line integral is the work done by a force F \vec{F} F : W = ∫ F ⋅ d l W = \int \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{l} W = ∫ F ⋅ d l Ordinarily, the value of a line integral depends critically on the path taken from a to b, but there is an important special class of vector functions for which the line integral is independent of path and is determined entirely by the end points. It will be our business in due course to characterize this special class of vectors. (A force that has this property is called conservative. )

docs.text: A surface integral is an expression of the form ∫ S v ⋅ d a (1.50) \int_{\mathscr{S}} \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} \tagl{1.50} ∫ S ​ v ⋅ d a ( 1 . 5 0 ) where v is again some vector function, and the integral is over a specified surface S \mathscr{S} S . Here d a \dd \vec{a} d a is an infinitesimal patch of area, with direction perpendicular to the surface (Fig 1.22). There are, of course, two directions perpendicular to any surface, so the sign of a surface integral is intrinsically ambiguous. If the surface is closed (forming a "balloon"), in which case I again put a circle on the integral sign ∮ v ⋅ d a \oint \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} ∮ v ⋅ d a then tradition dictates that "outward" is positive, but for open surfaces it's arbitrary. If v describes the flow of a fluid (mass per unit area per unit time), then ∫ v ⋅ d a \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} ∫ v ⋅ d a represents the total mass per unit time passing through the surface - hence the alternative name, "flux." Ordinarily, the value of a surface integral depends on the particular surface chosen, but there is a special class of vector functions for which it is independent of the surface and is determined entirely by the boundary line. An important task will be to characterize this special class of functions.

In Cartesian coordinates, d τ = d x   d y   d z (1.52) \dd \tau = \dd x \, \dd y \, \dd z \tagl{1.52} d τ = d x d y d z ( 1 . 5 2 ) For example, if T is the density of a substance (which might vary from point to point), then the volume integral would give the total mass. Occasionally we shall encounter volume integrals of vector functions: ∫ v d τ = ∫ ( v x x ^ + v y y ^ + v z z ^ ) d τ = x ^ ∫ v x d τ + y ^ ∫ v y d τ + z ^ ∫ v z d τ (1.53) \int \vec{v} \dd \tau = \int (v_x \vu{x} + v_y \vu{y} + v_z \vu{z}) \dd \tau = \vu{x} \int v_x \dd \tau + \vu{y} \int v_y \dd \tau + \vu{z} \int v_z \dd \tau \tagl{1.53} ∫ v d τ = ∫ ( v x ​ x ^ + v y ​ y ^ ​ + v z ​ z ^ ) d τ = x ^ ∫ v x ​ d τ + y ^ ​ ∫ v y ​ d τ + z ^ ∫ v z ​ d τ ( 1 . 5 3 ) Because the unit vectors are constants, they come outside the integral.

docs.text: Suppose f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) is a function in one variable. The fundamental theorem of calculus says ∫ a b ( d   f d   x ) d x = f ( b ) − f ( a ) (1.54) \int_a ^b \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) \dd x = f(b) - f(a) \tagl{1.54} ∫ a b ​ ( d x d f ​ ) d x = f ( b ) − f ( a ) ( 1 . 5 4 ) In case this doesn't look familiar, I'll write it another way: ∫ a b F ( x ) d x = f ( b ) − f ( a ) \int_a ^b F(x) \dd x = f(b) - f(a) ∫ a b ​ F ( x ) d x = f ( b ) − f ( a ) where d f / d x = F ( x ) df / dx = F(x) d f / d x = F ( x ) . The fundamental theorem tells you how to integrate F ( x ) F(x) F ( x ) : you think up a function f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) whose derivative is equal to F. Geometrical interpretation : According to Eq. 1.33, d f = ( d f / d x ) d x df = (df / dx) dx d f = ( d f / d x ) d x is the infinitesimal change in f when you go from (x) to (x + dx). The fundamental theorem (Eq. 1.54) says that if you chop the interval from a to b (Fig. 1.25) into many tiny pieces, dx, and add up the increments df from each little piece, the result is (not surprisingly) equal to the total change in f: f ( b ) − f ( a ) f(b) - f(a) f ( b ) − f ( a ) . In other words, there are two ways to determine the total change in the function: either subtract the values at the ends or go step-by-step, adding up all the tiny increments as you go. You'll get the same answer either way. Notice the basic format of the fundamental theorem: the integral of a derivative over some region is given by the value of the function at the end points (boundaries). In vector calculus there are three species of derivative (gradient, divergence, and curl), and each has its own "fundamental theorem," with essentially the same format. I don't plan to prove these theorems here; rather, I will explain what they mean, and try to make them plausible.
docs.title: 1.3.2: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

docs.text: Suppose we have a scalar function of three variables T(x, y, z). Starting at point a , we move a small distance d l 1 \dd \vec{l}_1 d l 1 ​ (Fig 1.26). According to Eq. 1.37, the function T will change by an amount d T = ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l 1 \dd T = (\grad T) \cdot \dd \vec{l}_1 d T = ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l 1 ​ Now we move a little further, by an additional small displacement d l 2 \dd \vec{l}_2 d l 2 ​ ; the incremental change in T will be ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l 2 (\grad T) \cdot \dd \vec{l}_2 ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l 2 ​ . In this manner, proceeding by infinitesimal steps, we make the journey to point b. At each step we compute the gradient of T (at that point) and dot it into the displacement dl... this gives us the change in T. Evidently the total change in Tin going from a to b (along the path selected) is ∫ a b ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l = T ( b ) − T ( a ) (1.55) \int_{\vec{a}} ^{\vec{b}} (\grad T) \cdot \dd \vec{l} = T(\vec{b}) - T(\vec{a}) \tagl{1.55} ∫ a b ​ ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l = T ( b ) − T ( a ) ( 1 . 5 5 ) This is the fundamental theorem for gradients; like the "ordinary" fundamental theorem, it says that the integral (here a line integral) of a derivative (here the gradient) is given by the value of the function at the boundaries (a and b). Geometrical Interpretation: Suppose you wanted to determine the height of the Eiffel Tower. You could climb the stairs, using a ruler to measure the rise at each step, and adding them all up (that's the left side of Eq. 1.55), or you could place altimeters at the top and the bottom, and subtract the two readings (that's the right side); you should get the same answer either way (that's the fundamental theorem). Incidentally, as we found in Ex. 1.6, line integrals ordinarily depend on the path taken from a to b. But the right side of Eq. 1.55 makes no reference to the path - only to the end points. Evidently, gradients have the special property that their line integrals are path independent: Corollary 1: ∫ a b ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l \int_a ^b (\grad T) \cdot \dd \vec{l} ∫ a b ​ ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l is independent of the path taken from a to b. Corollary 2: ∮ ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l = 0 \oint (\grad T) \cdot \dd \vec{l} = 0 ∮ ( ∇ T ) ⋅ d l = 0 , since the beginning and end points are identical, and hence T ( b ) − T ( a ) = 0 T(\vec{b}) - T(\vec{a}) = 0 T ( b ) − T ( a ) = 0 .
docs.title: 1.3.3: The Fundamental Theorem for Gradients

docs.text: Let T = x y 2 T = xy^2 T = x y 2 , and take point a to be the origin (0, 0, 0) and b to be the point (2, 1, 0). Check the fundamental theorem for gradients. Solution We know a priori that the integral should be independent of the path, but we must sill pick a specific path in order to evaluate it. Let's go out along the x axis, then up (Fig 1.27). As always, d l = d x x ^ + d y y ^ + d z z ^ ; ∇ T = y 2 x ^ + 2 x y y ^ \dd \vec{l} = \dd x \vu{x} + \dd y \vu{y} + \dd z \vu{z}; \grad T = y^2 \vu{x} + 2xy \vu{y} d l = d x x ^ + d y y ^ ​ + d z z ^ ; ∇ T = y 2 x ^ + 2 x y y ^ ​ y = 0 ; d l = d x x ^ ; ∇ T ⋅ d l = y 2 d x = 0 → ∫ i ∇ T ⋅ d l = 0 y = 0; \dd \vec{l} = \dd x \vu{x}; \grad T \cdot \dd \vec{l} = y^2 \dd x = 0 \rightarrow \int_{i} \grad T \cdot \dd \vec{l} = 0 y = 0 ; d l = d x x ^ ; ∇ T ⋅ d l = y 2 d x = 0 → ∫ i ​ ∇ T ⋅ d l = 0 x = 2 ; d l = d y y ^ ; ∇ T ⋅ d l = 4 y d y → ∫ i i ∇ T ⋅ d l = 2 y 2 ∣ 0 1 = 2 x = 2; \dd \vec{l} = \dd y \vu{y}; \grad T \cdot \dd \vec{l} = 4y \dd y \rightarrow \int_{ii} \grad T \cdot \dd \vec{l} = \left. 2y^2 \right| _0 ^1 = 2 x = 2 ; d l = d y y ^ ​ ; ∇ T ⋅ d l = 4 y d y → ∫ i i ​ ∇ T ⋅ d l = 2 y 2 ∣ ∣ ∣ ​ 0 1 ​ = 2 The total line integral is 2. So is this consistent with what we expect from the fundamental theorem? Well, T ( b ) − T ( a ) = 2 − 0 = 2 T(b) - T(a) = 2 - 0 = 2 T ( b ) − T ( a ) = 2 − 0 = 2 , so yes!

docs.text: The fundamental theorem for divergences states that ∫ V ( ∇ ⋅ v ) d τ = ∮ S v ⋅ d a (1.56) \int _{\mathscr{V}} (\div \vec{v} ) \dd \tau = \oint_{\mathscr{S}} \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} \tagl{1.56} ∫ V ​ ( ∇ ⋅ v ) d τ = ∮ S ​ v ⋅ d a ( 1 . 5 6 ) In honor, I suppose, of its great importance, this theorem has at least three special names: Gauss's theorem , Green's theorem , or simply the divergence theorem . Like the other "fundamental theorems," it says that the integral of a derivative (in this case the divergence) over a region (in this case a volume, V) is equal to the value of the function at the boundary (in this case the surface S that bounds the volume). Notice that the boundary term is itself an integral (specifically, a surface integral). This is reasonable: the "boundary" of a line is just two end points, but the boundary of a volume is a (closed) surface. Geometrical Interpretation: If v represents the flow of an incompressible fluid, then the flux of v (the right side of Eq. 1.56) is the total amount of fluid passing out through the surface, per unit time. Now, the divergence measures the "spreading out" of the vectors from a point-a place of high divergence is like a "faucet," pouring out liquid. If we have a bunch of faucets in a region filled with incompressible fluid, an equal amount of liquid will be forced out through the boundaries of the region. In fact, there are two ways we could determine how much is being produced: (a) we could count up all the faucets, recording how much each puts out, or (b) we could go around the boundary, measuring the flow at each point, and add it all up. You get the same answer either way: ∫ ( faucets within the volume ) = ∮ ( flow out through the surface ) \int (\text{faucets within the volume}) = \oint (\text{flow out through the surface}) ∫ ( faucets within the volume ) = ∮ ( flow out through the surface ) This, in essence, is what the divergence theorem says.

We have to it in six parts, for each face of the cube: ∫ v ⋅ d a = ∫ 0 1 d y ∫ 0 1 d z y 2 = 1 3 (i) \tag{i} \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = \int_0 ^1 \dd y \int_0 ^1 \dd z y^2 = \frac{1}{3} ∫ v ⋅ d a = ∫ 0 1 ​ d y ∫ 0 1 ​ d z y 2 = 3 1 ​ ( i ) ∫ v ⋅ d a = − ∫ 0 1 d y ∫ 0 1 d z y 2 = − 1 3 (ii) \tag{ii} \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = - \int _0 ^1 \dd y \int _0 ^1 \dd z y^2 = - \frac{1}{3} ∫ v ⋅ d a = − ∫ 0 1 ​ d y ∫ 0 1 ​ d z y 2 = − 3 1 ​ ( i i ) ∫ v ⋅ d a = ∫ 0 1 d x ∫ 0 1 d z ( 2 x + z 2 ) = 4 3 (iii) \tag{iii} \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = \int_0 ^1 \dd x \int_0 ^1 \dd z (2x + z^2) = \frac{4}{3} ∫ v ⋅ d a = ∫ 0 1 ​ d x ∫ 0 1 ​ d z ( 2 x + z 2 ) = 3 4 ​ ( i i i ) ∫ v ⋅ d a = − ∫ 0 1 d x ∫ 0 1 d z ( z 2 ) = − 1 3 (iv) \tag{iv} \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = - \int _0 ^1 \dd x \int _0 ^1 \dd z (z^2) = - \frac{1}{3} ∫ v ⋅ d a = − ∫ 0 1 ​ d x ∫ 0 1 ​ d z ( z 2 ) = − 3 1 ​ ( i v ) ∫ v ⋅ d a = ∫ 0 1 d x ∫ 0 1 d y ( 2 y ) = 1 (v) \tag{v} \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = \int_0 ^1 \dd x \int_0 ^1 \dd y (2y) = 1 ∫ v ⋅ d a = ∫ 0 1 ​ d x ∫ 0 1 ​ d y ( 2 y ) = 1 ( v ) ∫ v ⋅ d a = − ∫ 0 1 d x ∫ 0 1 d y ( 0 ) = 0 (vi) \tag{vi} \int \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = - \int _0 ^1 \dd x \int _0 ^1 \dd y (0) = 0 ∫ v ⋅ d a = − ∫ 0 1 ​ d x ∫ 0 1 ​ d y ( 0 ) = 0 ( v i ) So the total flux is ∮ S v ⋅ d a = 1 3 − 1 3 + 4 3 − 1 3 + 1 + 0 = 2 \oint _S \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{4}{3} - \frac{1}{3} + 1 + 0 = 2 ∮ S ​ v ⋅ d a = 3 1 ​ − 3 1 ​ + 3 4 ​ − 3 1 ​ + 1 + 0 = 2 as we should expect.

docs.text: The fundamental theorem for curls, which goes by the name Stokes' Theorem , states that ∫ S ( ∇ × V ) ⋅ d a = ∮ P v ⋅ d l (1.57) \int _S(\curl \vec{V}) \cdot \dd \vec{a} = \oint _P \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{l} \tagl{1.57} ∫ S ​ ( ∇ × V ) ⋅ d a = ∮ P ​ v ⋅ d l ( 1 . 5 7 ) As always, the integral of a derivative (here, the curl) over a region (here, a patch of surface, S) is equal to the value of the function at the boundary (here, the perimeter of the patch, P). As in the case of the divergence theorem, the boundary term is itself an integral-specifically, a closed line integral. Geometrical Interpretation: Recall that the curl measures the "twist" of the vectors v ; a region of high curl is a whirlpool - if you put a tiny paddle wheel there, it will rotate. Now, the integral of the curl over some surface (or, more precisely, the flux of the curl through that surface) represents the "total amount of swirl," and we can determine that just as well by going around the edge and finding how much the flow is following the boundary (Fig. 1.31). Indeed, ∮ v ⋅ d l \oint \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{l} ∮ v ⋅ d l is sometimes called the circulation of v. You may have noticed an apparent ambiguity in Stokes' theorem: concerning the boundary line integral, which way are we supposed to go around (clockwise or counterclockwise)? If we go the "wrong" way, we'll pick up an overall sign error. The answer is that it doesn't matter which way you go as long as you are consistent, for there is a compensating sign ambiguity in the surface integral: Which way does d a \dd \vec{a} d a point? For a closed surface (as in the divergence theorem), d a \dd \vec{a} d a points in the direction of the outward normal; but for an open surface, which way is "out"? Consistency in Stokes' theorem (as in all such matters) is given by the right-hand rule: if your fingers point in the direction of the line integral, then your thumb fixes the direction of d a \dd \vec{a} d a (Fig. 1.32). Now, there are plenty of surfaces (infinitely many) that share any given boundary line. Twist a paper clip into a loop, and dip it in soapy water. The soap film constitutes a surface, with the wire loop as its boundary. If you blow on it, the soap film will expand, making a larger surface, with the same boundary. Ordinarily, a flux integral depends critically on what surface you integrate over, but evidently this is not the case with curls. For Stokes' theorem says that ∫ ( ∇ × v ) ⋅ d a \int (\curl \vec{v}) \cdot \dd \vec{a} ∫ ( ∇ × v ) ⋅ d a is equal to the line integral of v \vec{v}\ v around the boundary, and the latter makes no reference to the specific surface you choose. Corollary 1: ∫ ( ∇ × v ) ⋅ d a \int (\curl \vec{v}) \cdot \dd \vec{a} ∫ ( ∇ × v ) ⋅ d a depends only on the boundary line, not on the particular surface used. Corollary 2: ∮ ( ∇ × v ) ⋅ d a = 0 \oint (\curl \vec{v}) \cdot \dd \vec{a} = 0 ∮ ( ∇ × v ) ⋅ d a = 0 for any closed surface, since the boundary line, like the mouth of a balloon, shrinks down to a point, and hence the right side of ( 1.57 ) \eqref{1.57} ( 1 . 5 7 ) vanishes.

docs.text: The technique known (awkwardly) as integration by parts exploits the product rule for derivatives: d   d   x ( f g ) = f ( d   g d   x ) + g ( d   f d   x ) \dv{}{x} (fg) = f \left( \dv{g}{x} \right) + g \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) d x d ​ ( f g ) = f ( d x d g ​ ) + g ( d x d f ​ ) Integrating both sides, and invoking the fundamental theorem, ∫ a b d   d   x ( f g ) d x = f g ∣ a b = ∫ a b f ( d   g d   x ) d x + ∫ a b g ( d   f d   x ) d x \int_a ^b \dv{}{x} (fg) \dd x = \left. fg \right| ^b _a = \int _a ^b f \left( \dv{g}{x} \right) \dd x + \int_a ^b g \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) \dd x ∫ a b ​ d x d ​ ( f g ) d x = f g ∣ a b ​ = ∫ a b ​ f ( d x d g ​ ) d x + ∫ a b ​ g ( d x d f ​ ) d x or ∫ a b f ( d   g d   x ) d x = − ∫ a b ( d   f d   x ) d x + f g ∣ a b (1.58) \int_a ^b f \left( \dv{g}{x} \right) \dd x = - \int_a ^b \left( \dv{f}{x} \right) \dd x + \left. fg \right| ^b _a \tagl{1.58} ∫ a b ​ f ( d x d g ​ ) d x = − ∫ a b ​ ( d x d f ​ ) d x + f g ∣ a b ​ ( 1 . 5 8 ) That's "integration by parts." It applies to the situation in which you are called upon to integrate the product of one function (f) and the derivative of another (g); it says you can transfer the derivative from g to f, at the cost of a minus sign and a boundary term.

docs.text: Evaluate the integral ``` \int _0 ^\infty x e^{-x} \dd x Solution The exponential can be expressed as a derivative: e − x = d   d   x ( − e − x ) e^{-x} = \dv{}{x} \left( - e^{-x} \right) e − x = d x d ​ ( − e − x ) in this case, then, f ( x ) = x f(x) = x f ( x ) = x , g ( x ) = − e − x g(x) = - e^{-x} g ( x ) = − e − x , and d f / d x = 1 df /dx = 1 d f / d x = 1 , so ∫ 0 ∞ x e − x d x = ∫ 0 ∞ e − x d x − x e − x ∣ 0 ∞ = − e − x ∣ 0 ∞ = 1 \int_0 ^\infty x e^{-x} \dd x = \int _0 ^{\infty} e^{-x} \dd x - \left. x e^{-x} \right| _{0} ^{\infty} = - \left. e^{-x} \right| _0 ^{\infty} = 1 ∫ 0 ∞ ​ x e − x d x = ∫ 0 ∞ ​ e − x d x − x e − x ∣ ∣ ∣ ​ 0 ∞ ​ = − e − x ∣ ∣ ∣ ​ 0 ∞ ​ = 1 We can exploit the product rules of vector calculus, together with the appropriate fundamental theorems, in exactly the same way. For example, integrating ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) = f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) + A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) \div (f\vec{A}) = f(\div \vec{A}) + \vec{A} \cdot (\grad f) ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) = f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) + A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) over a volume, and invoking the divergence theorem, yileds ∫ ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) d τ = ∫ f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ + ∫ A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ ∮ f A ⋅ d a \int \div (f \vec{A}) \dd \tau = \int f(\div \vec{A}) \dd \tau + \int \vec{A} \cdot (\grad f) \dd \tau \ \oint f \vec{A} \cdot \dd \vec{a} ∫ ∇ ⋅ ( f A ) d τ = ∫ f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ + ∫ A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ ∮ f A ⋅ d a or ∫ V f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ = − ∫ V A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ + ∮ S f A ⋅ d a (1.59) \int _V f(\div \vec{A}) \dd \tau = - \int _V \vec{A} \cdot (\grad f) \dd \tau + \oint _S f \vec{A} \cdot \dd \vec{a} \tagl{1.59} ∫ V ​ f ( ∇ ⋅ A ) d τ = − ∫ V ​ A ⋅ ( ∇ f ) d τ + ∮ S ​ f A ⋅ d a ( 1 . 5 9 ) Here again the integrand is the product of one function (f) and the derivative (in this case the divergence) of another ( A ), and integration by parts licenses us to transfer the derivative from A to f (where it becomes a gradient), at the cost of a minus sign and a boundary term (in this case a surface integral). In practice, this turns out to be one of the most useful tools at our disposal in vector calculus. Though you might wonder how often you're really likely to encounter an integral involving the product of one function and the derivative of another, the answer is surprisingly often .

docs.text: .katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 1.4: Curvilinear Coordinates 1.4.1: Spherical Coordinates You can label a point P by its Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z), but sometimes it is more convenient to use spherical coordinates ( r , θ , ϕ ) (r, \theta, \phi) ( r , θ , ϕ ) ; r r r is the distance from the origin (the magnitude of the position vector r ), θ \theta θ (the angle down from the z axis) is called the polar angle , and ϕ \phi ϕ (the angle around from the x axis) is the azimuthal angle . Their relation to Cartesian coordinates can be read trigonometrically from Fig 1.36: x = r sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ , y = r sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ , z = r cos ⁡ θ (1.62) x = r \sin \theta \cos \phi, \qquad y = r \sin \theta \sin \phi, \qquad z = r \cos \theta \tagl{1.62} x = r sin θ cos ϕ , y = r sin θ sin ϕ , z = r cos θ ( 1 . 6 2 ) Figure 1.36 also shows three unit vectors, r ^ , θ ^ , ϕ ^ \vu{r}, \vu{\theta}, \vu{\phi} r ^ , θ ^ , ϕ ^ ​ , pointing in the direction of increase of the corresponding coordinates. They constitute an orthogonal (mutually perpendicular) basis set (just like x ^ , y ^ , z ^ \vu{x}, \vu{y}, \vu{z} x ^ , y ^ ​ , z ^ ), and any vector A can be expressed in terms of them, in the usual way: A = A r r ^ + A θ θ ^ + A ϕ ϕ ^ (1.63) \vec{A} = A_r \vu{r} + A_\theta \vu{\theta} + A_\phi \vu{\phi} \tagl{1.63} A = A r ​ r ^ + A θ ​ θ ^ + A ϕ ​ ϕ ^ ​ ( 1 . 6 3 ) A r , A θ , A ϕ A_r, A_{\theta}, A_{\phi} A r ​ , A θ ​ , A ϕ ​ are the radial, polar, and azimuthal components of A . In terms of the Cartesian unit vectors, r ^ = sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ + cos ⁡ θ z ^ θ ^ = cos ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ − sin ⁡ θ z ^ ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ (1.64) \begin{aligned} \vu{r} & = \sin \theta \cos \phi \vu{x} + \sin \theta \sin \phi \vu{y} + \cos \theta \vu{z} \\ \vu{\theta} & = \cos \theta \cos \phi \vu{x} + \cos \theta \sin \phi \vu{y} - \sin \theta \vu{z} \\ \vu{\phi} & = - \sin \phi \vu{x} + \cos \phi \vu{y} \end{aligned} \tagl{1.64} r ^ θ ^ ϕ ^ ​ ​ = sin θ cos ϕ x ^ + sin θ sin ϕ y ^ ​ + cos θ z ^ = cos θ cos ϕ x ^ + cos θ sin ϕ y ^ ​ − sin θ z ^ = − sin ϕ x ^ + cos ϕ y ^ ​ ​ ( 1 . 6 4 ) as you can check for yourself (Prob 1.38). There is a poisonous snake lurking here that I'd better warn you about: r ^ \vu{r} r ^ , θ ^ \vu{\theta} θ ^ , and ϕ ^ \vu{\phi} ϕ ^ ​ are associated with a particular point P, and they change direction as P moves around. For example, r ^ \vu{r} r ^ always points radially outward, but "radially outward" can be in the x direction, the y direction, or any other direction, depending on where you are. In Fig. 1.37, A = y ^ \vec{A} = \vu{y} A = y ^ ​ and B = − y ^ \vec{B} = - \vu{y} B = − y ^ ​ , and yet both of them would be written as r ^ \vu{r} r ^ in spherical coordinates. One could take account of this by explicitly indicating the point of reference: r ^ ( θ , ϕ ) , θ ^ ( θ , ϕ ) , ϕ ^ ( θ , ϕ ) \vu{r}(\theta, \phi), \vu{\theta}(\theta, \phi), \vu{\phi}(\theta, \phi) r ^ ( θ , ϕ ) , θ ^ ( θ , ϕ ) , ϕ ^ ​ ( θ , ϕ ) , but this would be cumbersome, and as long as you are alert to the problem, I don't think it will cause difficulties. In particular, do not naively combine the spherical components of vectors associated with different points (in Fig. 1.37, A + B = 0 \vec{A} + \vec{B} = 0 A + B = 0 , not 2 r ^ 2 \vu{r} 2 r ^ , and A ⋅ B = − 1 \vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} = -1 A ⋅ B = − 1 , not + 1 +1 + 1 ). Beware of differentiating a vector that is expressed in spherical coordinates, since the unit vectors themselves are functions of position ( ∂ r ^ / ∂ θ = θ ^ \partial \vu{r} / \partial \theta = \vu{\theta} ∂ r ^ / ∂ θ = θ ^ , for example). And do not take r ^ , θ ^ , ϕ ^ \vu{r}, \vu{\theta}, \vu{\phi} r ^ , θ ^ , ϕ ^ ​ outside an integral, as I did with the Cartesian unit vectors. In general, if you're uncertain about the validity of an operation, rewrite the problem using Cartesian coordinates, for which this difficulty does not arise. An infinitesimal displacement in the r ^ \vu{r} r ^ direction is simply dr (Fig. 1.38a), just as an infinitesimal element of length in the x direction is dx: d l r = d r (1.65) \dd l_r = dr \tagl{1.65} d l r ​ = d r ( 1 . 6 5 ) On the other hand, an infinitesimal element of length in the θ ^ \vu{\theta} θ ^ direction (Fig 1.38b) is not just d θ \dd \theta d θ - that doesn't even have the right units for a length! Rather, d l θ = r d θ (1.66) \dd l_{\theta} = r \dd \theta \tagl{1.66} d l θ ​ = r d θ ( 1 . 6 6 ) Similarly, an infinitesimal element of length in the ϕ ^ \vu{\phi} ϕ ^ ​ direction (Fig 1.38c) is d l ϕ = r sin ⁡ θ d ϕ (1.67) \dd l_{\phi} = r \sin \theta \dd \phi \tagl{1.67} d l ϕ ​ = r sin θ d ϕ ( 1 . 6 7 ) so that we can write the general infinitesimal displacement as d l = d r r ^ + r d θ θ ^ + r sin ⁡ θ d ϕ ϕ ^ (1.68) \dd \vec{l} = \dd r \vu{r} + r \dd \theta \vu{\theta} + r \sin \theta \dd \phi \vu{\phi} \tagl{1.68} d l = d r r ^ + r d θ θ ^ + r sin θ d ϕ ϕ ^ ​ ( 1 . 6 8 ) This plays the role that d x x ^ + d y y ^ + d z z ^ \dd x \vu{x} + \dd y \vu{y} + \dd z \vu{z} d x x ^ + d y y ^ ​ + d z z ^ played in Cartesian coordinates. docs.text: You can label a point P by its Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z), but sometimes it is more convenient to use spherical coordinates ( r , θ , ϕ ) (r, \theta, \phi) ( r , θ , ϕ ) ; r r r is the distance from the origin (the magnitude of the position vector r ), θ \theta θ (the angle down from the z axis) is called the polar angle , and ϕ \phi ϕ (the angle around from the x axis) is the azimuthal angle . Their relation to Cartesian coordinates can be read trigonometrically from Fig 1.36: x = r sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ , y = r sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ , z = r cos ⁡ θ (1.62) x = r \sin \theta \cos \phi, \qquad y = r \sin \theta \sin \phi, \qquad z = r \cos \theta \tagl{1.62} x = r sin θ cos ϕ , y = r sin θ sin ϕ , z = r cos θ ( 1 . 6 2 ) Figure 1.36 also shows three unit vectors, r ^ , θ ^ , ϕ ^ \vu{r}, \vu{\theta}, \vu{\phi} r ^ , θ ^ , ϕ ^ ​ , pointing in the direction of increase of the corresponding coordinates. They constitute an orthogonal (mutually perpendicular) basis set (just like x ^ , y ^ , z ^ \vu{x}, \vu{y}, \vu{z} x ^ , y ^ ​ , z ^ ), and any vector A can be expressed in terms of them, in the usual way: A = A r r ^ + A θ θ ^ + A ϕ ϕ ^ (1.63) \vec{A} = A_r \vu{r} + A_\theta \vu{\theta} + A_\phi \vu{\phi} \tagl{1.63} A = A r ​ r ^ + A θ ​ θ ^ + A ϕ ​ ϕ ^ ​ ( 1 . 6 3 ) A r , A θ , A ϕ A_r, A_{\theta}, A_{\phi} A r ​ , A θ ​ , A ϕ ​ are the radial, polar, and azimuthal components of A . In terms of the Cartesian unit vectors, r ^ = sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ + cos ⁡ θ z ^ θ ^ = cos ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ − sin ⁡ θ z ^ ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ (1.64) \begin{aligned} \vu{r} & = \sin \theta \cos \phi \vu{x} + \sin \theta \sin \phi \vu{y} + \cos \theta \vu{z} \\ \vu{\theta} & = \cos \theta \cos \phi \vu{x} + \cos \theta \sin \phi \vu{y} - \sin \theta \vu{z} \\ \vu{\phi} & = - \sin \phi \vu{x} + \cos \phi \vu{y} \end{aligned} \tagl{1.64} r ^ θ ^ ϕ ^ ​ ​ = sin θ cos ϕ x ^ + sin θ sin ϕ y ^ ​ + cos θ z ^ = cos θ cos ϕ x ^ + cos θ sin ϕ y ^ ​ − sin θ z ^ = − sin ϕ x ^ + cos ϕ y ^ ​ ​ ( 1 . 6 4 ) as you can check for yourself (Prob 1.38). There is a poisonous snake lurking here that I'd better warn you about: r ^ \vu{r} r ^ , θ ^ \vu{\theta} θ ^ , and ϕ ^ \vu{\phi} ϕ ^ ​ are associated with a particular point P, and they change direction as P moves around. For example, r ^ \vu{r} r ^ always points radially outward, but "radially outward" can be in the x direction, the y direction, or any other direction, depending on where you are. The relation to Cartesian coordinates is somewhat cleaner than the spherical sort x = s cos ⁡ ϕ , y = s sin ⁡ ϕ , z = z (1.74) x = s \cos \phi, \qquad y = s \sin \phi, \qquad z = z \tagl{1.74} x = s cos ϕ , y = s sin ϕ , z = z ( 1 . 7 4 ) The unit vectors (Prob 1.42) are s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ z ^ = z ^ (1.75) \begin{aligned} \vu{s} & = \cos \phi \vu{x} + \sin \phi \vu{y} \\ \vu{\phi} & = - \sin \phi \vu{x} + \cos \phi \vu{y} \\ \vu{z} & = \vu{z} \end{aligned} \tagl{1.75} s ^ ϕ ^ ​ z ^ ​ = cos ϕ x ^ + sin ϕ y ^ ​ = − sin ϕ x ^ + cos ϕ y ^ ​ = z ^ ​ ( 1 . 7 5 ) The infinitesimal displacements are d l s = d s , d l ϕ = s d ϕ , d l z = d z (1.76) dl_s = ds, \qquad dl_{\phi} = s \dd \phi, \qquad dl_z = dz \tagl{1.76} d l s ​ = d s , d l ϕ ​ = s d ϕ , d l z ​ = d z ( 1 . 7 6 ) so d l = d s s ^ + s d ϕ ϕ ^ + d z z ^ (1.77) \dd \vec{l} = ds \vu{s} + s \dd \phi \vu{\phi} + dz \vu{z} \tagl{1.77} d l = d s s ^ + s d ϕ ϕ ^ ​ + d z z ^ ( 1 . 7 7 ) and the volume element is d τ = s   d s   d ϕ   d z (1.78) \dd \tau = s \, \dd s \, \dd \phi \, \dd z \tagl{1.78} d τ = s d s d ϕ d z ( 1 . 7 8 ) The range of s is 0 → ∞ 0 \rightarrow \infty 0 → ∞ , ϕ \phi ϕ goes from 0 → 2 π 0 \rightarrow 2\pi 0 → 2 π , and z z z from − ∞ → ∞ -\infty \rightarrow \infty − ∞ → ∞ . The vector derivatives in cylindrical coordinates are: Gradient : ∇ T = ∂ T ∂ s s ^ + 1 s ∂ T ∂ ϕ ϕ ^ + ∂ T ∂ z z ^ (1.79) \grad T = \pdv{T}{s} \vu{s} + \frac{1}{s} \pdv{T}{\phi} \vu{\phi} + \pdv{T}{z} \vu{z} \tagl{1.79} ∇ T = ∂ s ∂ T ​ s ^ + s 1 ​ ∂ ϕ ∂ T ​ ϕ ^ ​ + ∂ z ∂ T ​ z ^ ( 1 . 7 9 ) Divergence : ∇ ⋅ v = 1 s ∂ ∂ s ( s v s ) + 1 s ∂ v ϕ ∂ ϕ + ∂ v z ∂ z (1.80) \div \vec{v} = \frac{1}{s} \pdv{}{s} (s v_s) + \frac{1}{s} \pdv{v_\phi}{\phi} + \pdv{v_z}{z} \tagl{1.80} ∇ ⋅ v = s 1 ​ ∂ s ∂ ​ ( s v s ​ ) + s 1 ​ ∂ ϕ ∂ v ϕ ​ ​ + ∂ z ∂ v z ​ ​ ( 1 . 8 0 ) Curl : ∇ × v = ( 1 s ∂ v z ∂ ϕ − ∂ v ϕ ∂ z ) s ^ + ( ∂ v s ∂ z − ∂ v z ∂ s ) ϕ ^ + 1 s [ ∂ ∂ s ( s v ϕ ) − ∂ v s ∂ ϕ ] z ^ (1.81) \begin{aligned} \curl \vec{v} = & \left( \frac{1}{s} \pdv{v_z}{\phi} - \pdv{v_{\phi}}{z} \right) \vu{s} \\ & + \left( \pdv{v_s}{z} - \pdv{v_z}{s} \right) \vu{\phi} \\ & + \frac{1}{s} \left[ \pdv{}{s} (s v_{\phi}) - \pdv{v_s}{\phi} \right] \vu{z} \end{aligned} \tagl{1.81} ∇ × v = ​ ( s 1 ​ ∂ ϕ ∂ v z ​ ​ − ∂ z ∂ v ϕ ​ ​ ) s ^ + ( ∂ z ∂ v s ​ ​ − ∂ s ∂ v z ​ ​ ) ϕ ^ ​ + s 1 ​ [ ∂ s ∂ ​ ( s v ϕ ​ ) − ∂ ϕ ∂ v s ​ ​ ] z ^ ​ ( 1 . 8 1 ) Laplacian : ∇ 2 T = 1 s ∂ ∂ s ( s ∂ T ∂ s ) + 1 s 2 ∂ 2 T ∂ ϕ 2 + ∂ 2 T ∂ z 2 (1.82) \laplacian T = \frac{1}{s} \pdv{}{s} \left( s \pdv{T}{s} \right) + \frac{1}{s^2} \frac{\partial ^2 T}{\partial \phi ^2} + \frac{\partial ^2 T}{\partial z^2} \tagl{1.82} ∇ 2 T = s 1 ​ ∂ s ∂ ​ ( s ∂ s ∂ T ​ ) + s 2 1 ​ ∂ ϕ 2 ∂ 2 T ​ + ∂ z 2 ∂ 2 T ​ ( 1 . 8 2 )

docs.text: .katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 1.5: The Dirac Delta Function 1.5.1: The Divergence of r ^ / r 2 \vu{r} / r^2 r ^ / r 2 Consider the vector function v = 1 r 2 r ^ (1.83) \vec{v} = \frac{1}{r^2} \vu{r} \tagl{1.83} v = r 2 1 ​ r ^ ( 1 . 8 3 ) At every location, v is directed radially outward (Fig. 1.44); if ever there was a function that ought to have a large positive divergence, this is it. And yet, when you actually calculate the divergence (using Eq. 1.71), you get precisely zero: ∇ ⋅ v = 1 r 2 ∂ ∂ r ( r 2 1 r 2 ) = 1 r 2 ∂ ∂ r ( 1 ) = 0 (1.84) \div \vec{v} = \frac{1}{r^2} \pdv{}{r} \left( r^2 \frac{1}{r^2} \right) = \frac{1}{r^2} \pdv{}{r} (1) = 0 \tagl{1.84} ∇ ⋅ v = r 2 1 ​ ∂ r ∂ ​ ( r 2 r 2 1 ​ ) = r 2 1 ​ ∂ r ∂ ​ ( 1 ) = 0 ( 1 . 8 4 ) (You will have encountered this paradox already, if you worked Prob. 1.16.) The plot thickens when we apply the divergence theorem to this function. Suppose we integrate over a sphere of radius R, centered at the origin (Prob. 1.38b); the surface integral is ∮ v ⋅ d a = ∫ ( 1 R 2 r ^ ) ⋅ ( R 2 sin ⁡ θ d θ d ϕ r ^ ) = ( ∫ 0 π sin ⁡ θ d θ ) ( ∫ 0 2 π d ϕ ) = 4 π (1.85) \begin{aligned} \oint \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} & = \int \left( \frac{1}{R^2} \vu{r} \right) \cdot (R^2 \sin \theta \dd \theta \dd \phi \vu{r}) \\ & = \left( \int_0 ^\pi \sin \theta \dd \theta \right) \left( \int_0 ^{2 \pi} \dd \phi \right) = 4 \pi \end{aligned} \tagl{1.85} ∮ v ⋅ d a ​ = ∫ ( R 2 1 ​ r ^ ) ⋅ ( R 2 sin θ d θ d ϕ r ^ ) = ( ∫ 0 π ​ sin θ d θ ) ( ∫ 0 2 π ​ d ϕ ) = 4 π ​ ( 1 . 8 5 ) But if we really believe ( 1.84 ) \eqref{1.84} ( 1 . 8 4 ) , then the volume integral ∫ ∇ ⋅ v d τ \int \div \vec{v} \dd \tau ∫ ∇ ⋅ v d τ must be zero. What the heck is going on here?? The source of the problem is obviously the point r = 0 r = 0 r = 0 , where v blows up (and where, in Eq. 1.84, we have unwittingly divided by zero). It is quite true that ∇ ⋅ v = 0 \div \vec{v} = 0 ∇ ⋅ v = 0 everywhere except the origin, but right at the origin the situation is more complicated. Notice that the surface integral (Eq. 1.85) is independent of R; if the divergence theorem is right (and it is), we should get ∫ ( ∇ ⋅ v ) d τ = 4 π \int (\div \vec{v}) \dd \tau = 4 \pi ∫ ( ∇ ⋅ v ) d τ = 4 π for any sphere centered at the origin, no matter how small. Evidently the entire contribution must be coming from the point r = 0 r = 0 r = 0 ! Thus, ∇ ⋅ v \div \vec{v} ∇ ⋅ v has the bizarre property that it vanishes everywhere except at one point, and yet its integral (over any volume containing that point) is 4 π 4 \pi 4 π . No ordinary function behaves like that. (On the other hand, a physical example does come to mind: the density (mass per unit volume) of a point particle. It's zero except at the exact location of the particle, and yet its integral is finite-namely, the mass of the particle.) What we have stumbled on is a mathematical object known to physicists as the Dirac delta function. It arises in many branches of theoretical physics. Moreover, the specific problem at hand (the divergence of the function r ^ / r 2 \vu{r} / r^2 r ^ / r 2 ) is not just some arcane curiosity - it is, in fact, central to the whole theory of electrodynamics. So it is worthwhile to pause here and study the Dirac delta function with some care. 1.5.2: The One-Dimensional Dirac Delta Function The one-dimensional Dirac delta function, δ ( x ) \delta(x) δ ( x ) , can be pictured as an infinitely high, infinitesimally narrow "spike," with area 1 (Fig 1.45). That is to say: δ ( x ) = { 0 , if x ≠ 0 ∞ , if x = 0 (1.86) \delta(x) = \begin{cases} 0, & \qquad \text{ if } x \neq 0 \\ \infty , & \qquad \text{ if } x = 0 \end{cases} \tagl{1.86} δ ( x ) = { 0 , ∞ , ​ if x  ​ = 0 if x = 0 ​ ( 1 . 8 6 ) and ∫ − ∞ ∞ δ ( x ) d x = 1 (1.87) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \delta(x) \dd x = 1 \tagl{1.87} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ δ ( x ) d x = 1 ( 1 . 8 7 ) Technically, δ ( x ) \delta(x) δ ( x ) is not a function at all, since its value is not finite at x = 0; in the mathematical literature it is known as a generalized function , or distribution . It is, if you like, the limit of a sequence of functions , such as rectangles R n ( x ) R_n(x) R n ​ ( x ) of height n n n and width 1 / n 1/n 1 / n , or isosceles triangles T n ( x ) T_n(x) T n ​ ( x ) of height n n n and base 2 / n 2/n 2 / n (Fig 1.46) If f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) is some "ordinary" function (let's just say continuous, just to be safe), then the product f ( x ) δ ( x ) f(x) \delta(x) f ( x ) δ ( x ) is zero everywhere except at x = 0. It follows that f ( x ) δ ( x ) = f ( 0 ) δ ( x ) (1.88) f(x) \delta(x) = f(0) \delta(x) \tagl{1.88} f ( x ) δ ( x ) = f ( 0 ) δ ( x ) ( 1 . 8 8 ) This is probably the most important fact about the delta function! Since the product is zero anyway except at x = 0, we may as well replace f(x) by the value it assumes at the origin. In particular, ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ∫ − ∞ ∞ δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) (1.89) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(x) \dd x = f(0) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \delta(x) \dd x = f(0) \tagl{1.89} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ( 1 . 8 9 ) Under an integral, then, the delta function "picks out" the value of f(x) at a particular point. Of course, the limits of integration need not be all space, as long as the origin is included. We can also shift the spike from x = 0 to some other point, x = a, as well (Fig 1.47) δ ( x − a ) = { 0 , if x ≠ a ∞ , if x = a with ∫ − ∞ ∞ δ ( x − a ) d x = 1 (1.90) \delta(x - a) = \begin{cases} 0, & \text{ if } x \neq a \\ \infty , & \text{ if } x = a \end{cases} \quad \text{ with } \quad \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \delta(x - a) \dd x = 1 \tagl{1.90} δ ( x − a ) = { 0 , ∞ , ​ if x  ​ = a if x = a ​ with ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ δ ( x − a ) d x = 1 ( 1 . 9 0 ) Equation ( 1.88 ) \eqref{1.88} ( 1 . 8 8 ) becomes f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) = f ( a ) δ ( x − a ) f(x) \delta(x - a) = f(a) \delta(x - a) f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) = f ( a ) δ ( x − a ) and ( 1.89 ) \eqref{1.89} ( 1 . 8 9 ) generalizes to ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) d x = f ( a ) (1.92) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(x - a) \dd x = f(a) \tagl{1.92} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) d x = f ( a ) ( 1 . 9 2 ) Example 1.14 Evaluate the integral math \int_0 ^3 x^3 \delta(x-2) \dd x math Solution Easy peasy. The delta function picks out the value of x 3 x^3 x 3 at the point x = 2, so the integral is 2 3 = 8 2^3 = 8 2 3 = 8 . Notice that if the limits of integration had not included x = 2, then the answer would be 0. Although δ ( x ) \delta(x) δ ( x ) itself is not a legitimate function, integrals over δ \delta δ are perfectly acceptable. In fact, it's best to think of the delta function as something that is always intended for use under an integral sign . In particular, two expressions involving delta functions are considered equal if ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) D 1 ( x ) d x = ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) D 2 ( x ) d x (1.93) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) D_1 (x) \dd x = \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) D_2 (x) \dd x \tagl{1.93} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) D 1 ​ ( x ) d x = ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) D 2 ​ ( x ) d x ( 1 . 9 3 ) for all ("ordinary") functions f(x). Example 1.15 Show that \delta(kx) = \frac{1}{|k||}\delta(x) where k is any (nonzero) constant. (In particular, δ ( − x ) = δ ( x ) . \delta(-x) = \delta(x). δ ( − x ) = δ ( x ) . ) Solution For an arbitrary test function f(x), consider the integral ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( k x ) d x \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(kx) \dd x ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( k x ) d x Changing variables, we let y ≡ k x y \equiv kx y ≡ k x so that x = y / k x = y/k x = y / k and d x = 1 / k d y \dd x = 1 / k \dd y d x = 1 / k d y . If k is positive, the integration still runs from − ∞ -\infty − ∞ to ∞ \infty ∞ , but if k is negative, then x = ∞ x = \infty x = ∞ implies y = − ∞ y = -\infty y = − ∞ , and vice versa, so the order of the limits is reversed. Restoring the "proper" order costs a minus sign. Thus ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( k x ) d x + ± ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( y / k ) δ ( y ) d y k = ± 1 k f ( 0 ) = 1 ∣ k ∣ f ( 0 ) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(kx) \dd x + \pm \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(y/k) \delta(y) \frac{dy}{k} = \pm \frac{1}{k} f(0) = \frac{1}{|k|} f(0) ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( k x ) d x + ± ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( y / k ) δ ( y ) k d y ​ = ± k 1 ​ f ( 0 ) = ∣ k ∣ 1 ​ f ( 0 ) (where here the lower signs apply when k is negative, and we account for this neatly by putting absolute value bars around the final k.) Under the integral sign, then, δ ( k x ) \delta(kx) δ ( k x ) serves the same purpose as ( 1 / ∣ k ∣ ) δ ( x ) (1/|k|)\delta(x) ( 1 / ∣ k ∣ ) δ ( x ) : ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( k x ) d x = ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) [ 1 ∣ k ∣ δ ( x ) ] d x \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(kx) \dd x = \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \left[ \frac{1}{|k|} \delta(x) \right] \dd x ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( k x ) d x = ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) [ ∣ k ∣ 1 ​ δ ( x ) ] d x According to our criterion ( 1.93 ) \eqref{1.93} ( 1 . 9 3 ) , therefore, δ ( k x ) \delta(kx) δ ( k x ) and ( 1 / ∣ k ∣ ) δ ( x ) (1/|k|)\delta(x) ( 1 / ∣ k ∣ ) δ ( x ) are equal. The Three-Dimensional Delta Function It is easy to generalize the delta function to three dimensions: δ 3 ( r ) = δ ( x ) δ ( y ) δ ( z ) (1.96) \delta ^3 (\vec{r}) = \delta(x) \delta(y) \delta(z) \tagl{1.96} δ 3 ( r ) = δ ( x ) δ ( y ) δ ( z ) ( 1 . 9 6 ) This three-dimensional delta function is zero everywhere except at (0, 0, 0), where it blows up. Its volume integral is 1. ∫ all space δ 3 ( r ) d τ = ∫ − ∞ ∞ d x ∫ − ∞ ∞ d y ∫ − ∞ ∞ d z δ ( x ) δ ( y ) δ ( z ) = 1 (1.97) \int_{\text{all space}} \delta ^3 (\vec{r}) \dd \tau = \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \dd x \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \dd y \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \dd z \delta(x) \delta(y) \delta(z) = 1 \tagl{1.97} ∫ all space ​ δ 3 ( r ) d τ = ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ d x ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ d y ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ d z δ ( x ) δ ( y ) δ ( z ) = 1 ( 1 . 9 7 ) And, generalizing ( 1.92 ) \eqref{1.92} ( 1 . 9 2 ) ∫ all space f ( r ) δ 3 ( r − a ) d τ = f ( a ) (1.98) \int_{\text{all space}} f(\vec{r}) \delta^3(\vec{r} - \vec{a}) \dd \tau = f(\vec{a}) \tagl{1.98} ∫ all space ​ f ( r ) δ 3 ( r − a ) d τ = f ( a ) ( 1 . 9 8 ) As in the one-dimensional case, integration with δ \delta δ picks out the value of the function f at the location of the spike. We are now in a position to resolve the paradox introduced in Sect. 1.5.1. As you will recall, we found that the divergence of r ^ / r 2 \vu{r}/r^2 r ^ / r 2 is zero everywhere except at the origin, and yet its integral over any volume containing the origin is a constant (to wit: 4 π 4\pi 4 π ). These are precisely the defining conditions for the Dirac delta function; evidently ∇ ⋅ ( r ^ r 2 ) = 4 π δ 3 ( r ) (1.99) \div \left( \frac{\vu{r}}{r^2} \right) = 4 \pi \delta^3(\vec{r}) \tagl{1.99} ∇ ⋅ ( r 2 r ^ ​ ) = 4 π δ 3 ( r ) ( 1 . 9 9 ) More generally, ∇ ⋅ ( γ ^ γ 2 ) = 4 π δ 3 ( γ ) (1.100) \div \left( \frac{\vu{\gr}}{\gr^2} \right) = 4 \pi \delta^3(\gr) \tagl{1.100} ∇ ⋅ ( γ 2 γ ^ ​ ​ ) = 4 π δ 3 ( γ ) ( 1 . 1 0 0 ) where, as always, γ \vec{\gr} γ is the separation vector γ ≡ r − r ′ \vec{\gr} \equiv \vec{r} - \vec{r'} γ ≡ r − r ′ . Note that differentiation here is with respect to r \vec{r} r , while r ′ \vec{r'} r ′ is held constant. Incidentally, since ∇ ( 1 γ ) = − γ ^ γ 2 \grad \left( \frac{1}{\gr} \right) = - \frac{\vu{\gr}}{\gr ^2} ∇ ( γ 1 ​ ) = − γ 2 γ ^ ​ ​ (from Problem 1.13), it follows that ∇ 2 1 γ = − 4 π δ 3 ( γ ) (1.102) \laplacian \frac{1}{\gr} = - 4 \pi \delta^3 (\vec{\gr}) \tagl{1.102} ∇ 2 γ 1 ​ = − 4 π δ 3 ( γ ) ( 1 . 1 0 2 ) Example 1.16 Evaluate the integral math J = \int_V (r^2 + 2) \div \left( \frac{\vu{r}}{r^2} \right) \dd \tau math where V V V is a sphere of radius R centered at the origin. Solution 1 Use ( 1.99 ) \eqref{1.99} ( 1 . 9 9 ) to rewrite the divergence, and ( 1.98 ) \eqref{1.98} ( 1 . 9 8 ) to do the integral: J = ∫ V ( r 2 + 2 ) 4 π δ 3 ( r ) d τ = 4 π ( 0 + 2 ) = 8 π J = \int_V (r^2 + 2) 4 \pi \delta ^3(\vec{r}) \dd \tau = 4 \pi (0 + 2) = 8 \pi J = ∫ V ​ ( r 2 + 2 ) 4 π δ 3 ( r ) d τ = 4 π ( 0 + 2 ) = 8 π This one-line solution demonstrates something of the power and beauty of the delta function, but I would like to show you a second method, which is much more cumbersome but serves to illustrate the method of integration by parts (Sect. 1.3.6). Solution 2 Using Eq 1.59, we transfer the derivative from r ^ / r 2 \vu{r}/r^2 r ^ / r 2 to ( r 2 + 2 ) (r^2 + 2) ( r 2 + 2 ) J = − ∫ V r ^ r 2 ⋅ [ ∇ ( r 2 + 2 ) ] d τ + ∮ S ( r 2 + 2 ) r ^ r 2 ⋅ d a J = - \int_V \frac{\vu{r}}{r^2} \cdot [\grad(r^2 + 2)] \dd \tau + \oint_S (r^2 + 2) \frac{\vu{r}}{r^2} \cdot \dd \vec{a} J = − ∫ V ​ r 2 r ^ ​ ⋅ [ ∇ ( r 2 + 2 ) ] d τ + ∮ S ​ ( r 2 + 2 ) r 2 r ^ ​ ⋅ d a The gradient is ∇ ( r 2 + 2 ) = 2 r r ^ \grad(r^2 + 2) = 2 r \vu{r} ∇ ( r 2 + 2 ) = 2 r r ^ so the volume integral becomes ∫ 2 r d τ = ∫ 2 r r 2 sin ⁡ θ d r d θ d ϕ = 8 π ∫ 0 R r d r = 4 π R 2 \int \frac{2}{r} \dd \tau = \int \frac{2}{r} r^2 \sin \theta \dd r \dd \theta \dd \phi = 8 \pi \int_0 ^R r \dd r = 4 \pi R^2 ∫ r 2 ​ d τ = ∫ r 2 ​ r 2 sin θ d r d θ d ϕ = 8 π ∫ 0 R ​ r d r = 4 π R 2 Meanwhile on the boundary of the sphere (where r = R) d a = R 2 sin ⁡ θ d θ d ϕ r ^ \dd \vec{a} = R^2 \sin \theta \dd \theta \dd \phi \vu{r} d a = R 2 sin θ d θ d ϕ r ^ so the surface integral is ∫ ( R 2 + 2 ) sin ⁡ θ d θ d ϕ = 4 π ( R 2 + 2 ) \int(R^2 + 2) \sin \theta \dd \theta \dd \phi = 4 \pi (R^2 + 2) ∫ ( R 2 + 2 ) sin θ d θ d ϕ = 4 π ( R 2 + 2 ) which, all together makes J = − 4 π R 2 + r π ( R 2 + 2 ) = 8 π J = -4 \pi R^2 + r \pi (R^2 + 2) = 8 \pi J = − 4 π R 2 + r π ( R 2 + 2 ) = 8 π In proper mathematical jargon, "sphere" denotes the surface, and "ball" the volume it encloses. But physicists are (as usual) sloppy about this sort of thing, and I use the word "sphere" for both the surface and the volume. docs.text: Consider the vector function v = 1 r 2 r ^ (1.83) \vec{v} = \frac{1}{r^2} \vu{r} \tagl{1.83} v = r 2 1 ​ r ^ ( 1 . 8 3 ) At every location, v is directed radially outward (Fig. 1.44); if ever there was a function that ought to have a large positive divergence, this is it. And yet, when you actually calculate the divergence (using Eq. 1.71), you get precisely zero: ∇ ⋅ v = 1 r 2 ∂ ∂ r ( r 2 1 r 2 ) = 1 r 2 ∂ ∂ r ( 1 ) = 0 (1.84) \div \vec{v} = \frac{1}{r^2} \pdv{}{r} \left( r^2 \frac{1}{r^2} \right) = \frac{1}{r^2} \pdv{}{r} (1) = 0 \tagl{1.84} ∇ ⋅ v = r 2 1 ​ ∂ r ∂ ​ ( r 2 r 2 1 ​ ) = r 2 1 ​ ∂ r ∂ ​ ( 1 ) = 0 ( 1 . 8 4 ) (You will have encountered this paradox already, if you worked Prob. 1.16.) The plot thickens when we apply the divergence theorem to this function. Suppose we integrate over a sphere of radius R, centered at the origin (Prob. 1.38b); the surface integral is ∮ v ⋅ d a = ∫ ( 1 R 2 r ^ ) ⋅ ( R 2 sin ⁡ θ d θ d ϕ r ^ ) = ( ∫ 0 π sin ⁡ θ d θ ) ( ∫ 0 2 π d ϕ ) = 4 π (1.85) \begin{aligned} \oint \vec{v} \cdot \dd \vec{a} & = \int \left( \frac{1}{R^2} \vu{r} \right) \cdot (R^2 \sin \theta \dd \theta \dd \phi \vu{r}) \\ & = \left( \int_0 ^\pi \sin \theta \dd \theta \right) \left( \int_0 ^{2 \pi} \dd \phi \right) = 4 \pi \end{aligned} \tagl{1.85} ∮ v ⋅ d a ​ = ∫ ( R 2 1 ​ r ^ ) ⋅ ( R 2 sin θ d θ d ϕ r ^ ) = ( ∫ 0 π ​ sin θ d θ ) ( ∫ 0 2 π ​ d ϕ ) = 4 π ​ ( 1 . 8 5 ) But if we really believe ( 1.84 ) \eqref{1.84} ( 1 . 8 4 ) , then the volume integral ∫ ∇ ⋅ v d τ \int \div \vec{v} \dd \tau ∫ ∇ ⋅ v d τ must be zero. What the heck is going on here?? The source of the problem is obviously the point r = 0 r = 0 r = 0 , where v blows up (and where, in Eq. 1.84, we have unwittingly divided by zero). It is quite true that ∇ ⋅ v = 0 \div \vec{v} = 0 ∇ ⋅ v = 0 everywhere except the origin, but right at the origin the situation is more complicated. Notice that the surface integral (Eq. 1.85) is independent of R; if the divergence theorem is right (and it is), we should get ∫ ( ∇ ⋅ v ) d τ = 4 π \int (\div \vec{v}) \dd \tau = 4 \pi ∫ ( ∇ ⋅ v ) d τ = 4 π for any sphere centered at the origin, no matter how small. Evidently the entire contribution must be coming from the point r = 0 r = 0 r = 0 ! Thus, ∇ ⋅ v \div \vec{v} ∇ ⋅ v has the bizarre property that it vanishes everywhere except at one point, and yet its integral (over any volume containing that point) is 4 π 4 \pi 4 π . No ordinary function behaves like that. (On the other hand, a physical example does come to mind: the density (mass per unit volume) of a point particle. It's zero except at the exact location of the particle, and yet its integral is finite-namely, the mass of the particle.) What we have stumbled on is a mathematical object known to physicists as the Dirac delta function. It arises in many branches of theoretical physics. Moreover, the specific problem at hand (the divergence of the function r ^ / r 2 \vu{r} / r^2 r ^ / r 2 ) is not just some arcane curiosity - it is, in fact, central to the whole theory of electrodynamics. So it is worthwhile to pause here and study the Dirac delta function with some care.

docs.text: The one-dimensional Dirac delta function, δ ( x ) \delta(x) δ ( x ) , can be pictured as an infinitely high, infinitesimally narrow "spike," with area 1 (Fig 1.45). That is to say: δ ( x ) = { 0 , if x ≠ 0 ∞ , if x = 0 (1.86) \delta(x) = \begin{cases} 0, & \qquad \text{ if } x \neq 0 \\ \infty , & \qquad \text{ if } x = 0 \end{cases} \tagl{1.86} δ ( x ) = { 0 , ∞ , ​ if x  ​ = 0 if x = 0 ​ ( 1 . 8 6 ) and ∫ − ∞ ∞ δ ( x ) d x = 1 (1.87) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \delta(x) \dd x = 1 \tagl{1.87} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ δ ( x ) d x = 1 ( 1 . 8 7 ) Technically, δ ( x ) \delta(x) δ ( x ) is not a function at all, since its value is not finite at x = 0; in the mathematical literature it is known as a generalized function , or distribution . It is, if you like, the limit of a sequence of functions , such as rectangles R n ( x ) R_n(x) R n ​ ( x ) of height n n n and width 1 / n 1/n 1 / n , or isosceles triangles T n ( x ) T_n(x) T n ​ ( x ) of height n n n and base 2 / n 2/n 2 / n (Fig 1.46) If f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) is some "ordinary" function (let's just say continuous, just to be safe), then the product f ( x ) δ ( x ) f(x) \delta(x) f ( x ) δ ( x ) is zero everywhere except at x = 0. It follows that f ( x ) δ ( x ) = f ( 0 ) δ ( x ) (1.88) f(x) \delta(x) = f(0) \delta(x) \tagl{1.88} f ( x ) δ ( x ) = f ( 0 ) δ ( x ) ( 1 . 8 8 ) This is probably the most important fact about the delta function! Since the product is zero anyway except at x = 0, we may as well replace f(x) by the value it assumes at the origin. In particular, ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ∫ − ∞ ∞ δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) (1.89) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(x) \dd x = f(0) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \delta(x) \dd x = f(0) \tagl{1.89} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ δ ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ( 1 . 8 9 ) Under an integral, then, the delta function "picks out" the value of f(x) at a particular point. Of course, the limits of integration need not be all space, as long as the origin is included. We can also shift the spike from x = 0 to some other point, x = a, as well (Fig 1.47) δ ( x − a ) = { 0 , if x ≠ a ∞ , if x = a with ∫ − ∞ ∞ δ ( x − a ) d x = 1 (1.90) \delta(x - a) = \begin{cases} 0, & \text{ if } x \neq a \\ \infty , & \text{ if } x = a \end{cases} \quad \text{ with } \quad \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} \delta(x - a) \dd x = 1 \tagl{1.90} δ ( x − a ) = { 0 , ∞ , ​ if x  ​ = a if x = a ​ with ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ δ ( x − a ) d x = 1 ( 1 . 9 0 ) Equation ( 1.88 ) \eqref{1.88} ( 1 . 8 8 ) becomes f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) = f ( a ) δ ( x − a ) f(x) \delta(x - a) = f(a) \delta(x - a) f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) = f ( a ) δ ( x − a ) and ( 1.89 ) \eqref{1.89} ( 1 . 8 9 ) generalizes to ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) d x = f ( a ) (1.92) \int_{-\infty} ^{\infty} f(x) \delta(x - a) \dd x = f(a) \tagl{1.92} ∫ − ∞ ∞ ​ f ( x ) δ ( x − a ) d x = f ( a ) ( 1 . 9 2 )

docs.text: Evaluate the integral math \int_0 ^3 x^3 \delta(x-2) \dd x math Solution Easy peasy. The delta function picks out the value of x 3 x^3 x 3 at the point x = 2, so the integral is 2 3 = 8 2^3 = 8 2 3 = 8 . docs.text: .katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 1.6: The Theory of Vector Fields 1.6.1: The Helmholtz Theorem Ever since Faraday, the laws of electricity and magnetism have been expressed in terms of electric and magnetic fields, E and B . Like many physical laws, these are most compactly expressed as differential equations. Since E and B are vectors, the differential equations naturally involve vector derivatives: divergence and curl. Indeed, Maxwell reduced the entire theory to four equations, specifying respectively the divergence and the curl of E and B . Maxwell's formulation raises an important mathematical question: To what extent is a vector function determined by its divergence and curl? In other words, if I tell you that the divergence of F (which stands for E or B , as the case may be) is a specified (scalar) function D, ∇ ⋅ F = D \div \vec{F} = D ∇ ⋅ F = D and the curl of F is a specified (vector) function C , ∇ × F = C \curl \vec{F} = \vec{C} ∇ × F = C can you then determine the function F ? Well... not quite. For example, as you may have discovered in Prob. 1.20, there are many functions whose divergence and curl are both zero everywhere - the trivial case F = 0 \vec{F} = 0 F = 0 , of course, but also F = y z x ^ + z x y ^ + x y z ^ , F = sin ⁡ x cosh ⁡ y x ^ − cos ⁡ x sinh ⁡ y y ^ \vec{F} = yz \vu{x} + zx \vu{y} + xy \vu{z}, \vec{F} = \sin x \cosh y \vu{x} - \cos x \sinh y \vu{y} F = y z x ^ + z x y ^ ​ + x y z ^ , F = sin x cosh y x ^ − cos x sinh y y ^ ​ , etc. To solve a differential equation you must also be supplied with appropriate boundary conditions . In electrodynamics we typically require that the fields go to zero "at infinity" (far away from all charges). With that extra information, the Helmholtz theorem guarantees that the field is uniquely determined by its divergence and curl. (The Helmholtz theorem is discussed in Appendix B.) 1.6.2: Potentials If the curl of a vector field ( F ) vanishes (everywhere), then F can be written as the gradient of a scalar potential (V): ∇ × F = 0 ⟺ F = − ∇ V (1.103) \curl \vec{F} = 0 \Longleftrightarrow \vec{F} = - \grad V \tagl{1.103} ∇ × F = 0 ⟺ F = − ∇ V ( 1 . 1 0 3 ) (The minus sign is purely conventional.) That's the essential burden of the following theorem: Theorem 1 . Curl-less (or 'irrotational') fields. The following conditions are equivalent (that is, F satisfies one if and only if it satisfies all the others): ∇ × F = 0 everywhere (a) \tag{a} \curl \vec{F} = 0 \text{ everywhere } ∇ × F = 0 everywhere ( a ) ∫ a b F ⋅ d l is independent of path, for any given end points (b) \tag{b} \int_a ^b \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{l} \text{ is independent of path, for any given end points} ∫ a b ​ F ⋅ d l is independent of path, for any given end points ( b ) ∮ F ⋅ d l = 0 for any closed loop (c) \tag{c} \oint \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{l} = 0 \text{ for any closed loop} ∮ F ⋅ d l = 0 for any closed loop ( c ) F is the gradient of some scalar function: F = − ∇ V (d) \tag{d} \vec{F} \text{ is the gradient of some scalar function: } \vec{F} = - \grad V F is the gradient of some scalar function: F = − ∇ V ( d ) The potential is not unique, and any constant can be added to V with impunity, since this will not affect its gradient. If the divergence of a vector field ( F ) vanishes (everywhere), then F can be expressed as the curl of a vector potential ( A ): ∇ ⋅ F = 0 ⟺ F = ∇ × A (1.104) \div \vec{F} = 0 \Longleftrightarrow \vec{F} = \curl \vec{A} \tagl{1.104} ∇ ⋅ F = 0 ⟺ F = ∇ × A ( 1 . 1 0 4 ) That's the main conclusion of the following theorem: Theorem 2 . Divergence-less (or 'solenoidal') fields. The following conditions are equivalent: ∇ ⋅ F = 0 everywhere (a) \tag{a} \div \vec{F} = 0 \text{ everywhere} ∇ ⋅ F = 0 everywhere ( a ) ∫ F ⋅ d a is independent of surface, for any given boundary line (b) \tag{b} \int \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{a} \text{ is independent of surface, for any given boundary line} ∫ F ⋅ d a is independent of surface, for any given boundary line ( b ) ∮ F ⋅ d a = 0 for any closed surface. (c) \tag{c} \oint \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = 0 \text{ for any closed surface.} ∮ F ⋅ d a = 0 for any closed surface. ( c ) F is the curl of some vector function: F = ∇ × A (d) \tag{d} \vec{F} \text{ is the curl of some vector function: } \vec{F} = \curl \vec{A} F is the curl of some vector function: F = ∇ × A ( d ) The vector potential is not unique - the gradient of any scalar function can be added to A without affecting the curl, since the curl of a gradient is zero. Incidentally, in all cases (whatever its curl and divergence may be), a vector field F can be written as the gradient of a scalar plus the curl of a vector: F = − ∇ V + ∇ × A (always) (1.50) \vec{F} = - \grad V + \curl \vec{A} \quad \text{(always)} \tagl{1.50} F = − ∇ V + ∇ × A (always) ( 1 . 5 0 ) In physics, the word field denotes generically any function of position (x, y, z) and time (t). But in electrodynamics two particular fields ( E and B ) are of such paramount importance as to preempt the term. Thus technically the potentials are also "fields," but we never call them that.

Indeed, Maxwell reduced the entire theory to four equations, specifying respectively the divergence and the curl of E and B . In other words, if I tell you that the divergence of F (which stands for E or B , as the case may be) is a specified (scalar) function D, ∇ ⋅ F = D \div \vec{F} = D ∇ ⋅ F = D and the curl of F is a specified (vector) function C , ∇ × F = C \curl \vec{F} = \vec{C} ∇ × F = C can you then determine the function F ? Well... not quite. For example, as you may have discovered in Prob. 1.20, there are many functions whose divergence and curl are both zero everywhere - the trivial case F = 0 \vec{F} = 0 F = 0 , of course, but also F = y z x ^ + z x y ^ + x y z ^ , F = sin ⁡ x cosh ⁡ y x ^ − cos ⁡ x sinh ⁡ y y ^ \vec{F} = yz \vu{x} + zx \vu{y} + xy \vu{z}, \vec{F} = \sin x \cosh y \vu{x} - \cos x \sinh y \vu{y} F = y z x ^ + z x y ^ ​ + x y z ^ , F = sin x cosh y x ^ − cos x sinh y y ^ ​ , etc. To solve a differential equation you must also be supplied with appropriate boundary conditions . In electrodynamics we typically require that the fields go to zero "at infinity" (far away from all charges). With that extra information, the Helmholtz theorem guarantees that the field is uniquely determined by its divergence and curl. (The Helmholtz theorem is discussed in Appendix B.)

docs.text: If the curl of a vector field ( F ) vanishes (everywhere), then F can be written as the gradient of a scalar potential (V): ∇ × F = 0 ⟺ F = − ∇ V (1.103) \curl \vec{F} = 0 \Longleftrightarrow \vec{F} = - \grad V \tagl{1.103} ∇ × F = 0 ⟺ F = − ∇ V ( 1 . 1 0 3 ) (The minus sign is purely conventional.) That's the essential burden of the following theorem: Theorem 1 . Curl-less (or 'irrotational') fields. The following conditions are equivalent (that is, F satisfies one if and only if it satisfies all the others): ∇ × F = 0 everywhere (a) \tag{a} \curl \vec{F} = 0 \text{ everywhere } ∇ × F = 0 everywhere ( a ) ∫ a b F ⋅ d l is independent of path, for any given end points (b) \tag{b} \int_a ^b \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{l} \text{ is independent of path, for any given end points} ∫ a b ​ F ⋅ d l is independent of path, for any given end points ( b ) ∮ F ⋅ d l = 0 for any closed loop (c) \tag{c} \oint \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{l} = 0 \text{ for any closed loop} ∮ F ⋅ d l = 0 for any closed loop ( c ) F is the gradient of some scalar function: F = − ∇ V (d) \tag{d} \vec{F} \text{ is the gradient of some scalar function: } \vec{F} = - \grad V F is the gradient of some scalar function: F = − ∇ V ( d ) The potential is not unique, and any constant can be added to V with impunity, since this will not affect its gradient. If the divergence of a vector field ( F ) vanishes (everywhere), then F can be expressed as the curl of a vector potential ( A ): ∇ ⋅ F = 0 ⟺ F = ∇ × A (1.104) \div \vec{F} = 0 \Longleftrightarrow \vec{F} = \curl \vec{A} \tagl{1.104} ∇ ⋅ F = 0 ⟺ F = ∇ × A ( 1 . 1 0 4 ) That's the main conclusion of the following theorem: Theorem 2 . Divergence-less (or 'solenoidal') fields. The following conditions are equivalent: ∇ ⋅ F = 0 everywhere (a) \tag{a} \div \vec{F} = 0 \text{ everywhere} ∇ ⋅ F = 0 everywhere ( a ) ∫ F ⋅ d a is independent of surface, for any given boundary line (b) \tag{b} \int \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{a} \text{ is independent of surface, for any given boundary line} ∫ F ⋅ d a is independent of surface, for any given boundary line ( b ) ∮ F ⋅ d a = 0 for any closed surface. (c) \tag{c} \oint \vec{F} \cdot \dd \vec{a} = 0 \text{ for any closed surface.} ∮ F ⋅ d a = 0 for any closed surface. ( c ) F is the curl of some vector function: F = ∇ × A (d) \tag{d} \vec{F} \text{ is the curl of some vector function: } \vec{F} = \curl \vec{A} F is the curl of some vector function: F = ∇ × A ( d ) The vector potential is not unique - the gradient of any scalar function can be added to A without affecting the curl, since the curl of a gradient is zero. Incidentally, in all cases (whatever its curl and divergence may be), a vector field F can be written as the gradient of a scalar plus the curl of a vector: F = − ∇ V + ∇ × A (always) (1.50) \vec{F} = - \grad V + \curl \vec{A} \quad \text{(always)} \tagl{1.50} F = − ∇ V + ∇ × A (always) ( 1 . 5 0 ) In physics, the word field denotes generically any function of position (x, y, z) and time (t). But in electrodynamics two particular fields ( E and B ) are of such paramount importance as to preempt the term. Thus technically the potentials are also "fields," but we never call them that.

Some sample topics will be put it. It should be thematically related to what we've been talking about, and you should be making connections to things we've been talking about (waveguides, waves, generation of waves, etc.) There will be two class periods in the last week which are reserved for presentations of about 15 minutes each. Examples of possible topics: Applications of X-ray radiation Advanced light source Advanced photon source Waveguiding Optical fibers Applications of coaxial cables Microwave cavities ADMX experiment Atom-photon entanglement with Rydberg atoms in high finesse cavities Optical interferometry Fabry-Perot interferometer / cavity and applications LIGO and gravitational waves Microcavities, Photonic crystal cavities 10.1.1 Scalar and Vector Potentials Ultimately the question of electromagnetism is given some sources ρ ( r , t ) \rho(\vec r, t) ρ ( r , t ) and J ( r , t ) \vec J ( \vec r, t) J ( r , t ) , what are the resulting fields E ( r , t ) \vec E( \vec r, t) E ( r , t ) and B ( r , t ) \vec B ( \vec r, t) B ( r , t ) ? In the static case, Coulomb's law and the Biot-Savart law provide deterministic answers, so how do we then generalize to time-dependent configurations? Just like in electrostatics, ∇ × E = 0 \curl \vec E = 0 ∇ × E = 0 allowed us to write E \vec E E as the gradient of a scalar potential. If we naively read off the retarded potential V ( r , t ) = 1 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ) γ d τ ′ V(\vec r, t) = \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \int \frac{\rho(\vec r', t_r)}{\gr} \dd \tau' V ( r , t ) = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ ∫ γ ρ ( r ′ , t r ​ ) ​ d τ ′ might suggest that the potential is just 1 4 π ϵ 0 q γ \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \frac{q}{\gr} 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ γ q ​ But that's wrong for a subtle reason: It is true that for a point source γ \gr γ comes outside the integral, but the remainder ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ) d τ ′ \int \rho(\vec r', t_r) \dd \tau' ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ​ ) d τ ′ is not equal to the charge of the particle, and depends on the location of the point r \vec r r . To calculate the total charge of a configuration, you must integrate ρ \rho ρ over the entire distribution at one instant of time, but here the retardation t r = t − γ / c t_r = t - \gr / c t r ​ = t − γ / c , obliges us to evaluate ρ \rho ρ at different times for different parts of the configuration. If the source is moving, this will give a distorted picture of the total charge. You might think that this problem would disappear for point charges, but it doesn't. In Maxwell's electrodynamics, formulated as it is in terms of charge and current densities, a point charge must be regarded as the limit of an extended charge, when the size goes to zero. And for an extended particle, no matter how small, the retardation throws a factor ( 1 − γ ^ ⋅ v / c ) − 1 (1 - \vu \gr \cdot \vec v / c)^{-1} ( 1 − γ ^ ​ ⋅ v / c ) − 1 where v \vec v v is the velocity of the charge at the retarded time ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ) d τ ′ = q 1 − γ ^ ⋅ v / c \int \rho ( \vec r ', t_r) \dd \tau' = \frac{q}{1 - \vu \gr \cdot \vec v / c} ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ​ ) d τ ′ = 1 − γ ^ ​ ⋅ v / c q ​ Proof : ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ) d τ ′ = q 1 − γ ^ ⋅ v / c \int \rho ( \vec r ', t_r) \dd \tau' = \frac{q}{1 - \vu \gr \cdot \vec v / c} ∫ ρ ( r ′ , t r ​ ) d τ ′ = 1 − γ ^ ​ ⋅ v / c q ​ This is a purely geometrical effect, and it may help to tell the story in a less abstract context. This looks like two metal spheres separated by distance d d d and connected by a small wire; at time t t t the charge on the upper sphere is q ( t ) q(t) q ( t ) and the charge on the lower sphere is − q ( t ) -q(t) − q ( t ) . We drive the charge back and forth through the wire from one sphere to the other at an angular frequency ω \omega ω q ( t ) = q 0 cos ⁡ ( ω t ) q(t) = q_0 \cos (\omega t) q ( t ) = q 0 ​ cos ( ω t ) The dipole moment is p ( t ) = p 0 cos ⁡ ( ω t ) z ^ p 0 ≡ q 0 d \vec p(t) = p_0 \cos (\omega t) \vu z \qquad p_0 \equiv q_0 d p ( t ) = p 0 ​ cos ( ω t ) z ^ p 0 ​ ≡ q 0 ​ d Of course, we consider the harmonically oscillating dipole because we can build any other oscillations out of this basis. The retarded potential of this oscillating dipole is the superposition of the two point charges: V ( r , t ) = 1 4 π ϵ 0 [ q 0 cos ⁡ [ ω ( t − γ + / c ) ] γ + − q 0 cos ⁡ [ ω ( t − γ − / c ) ] γ − ] V(\vec r, t) = \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \left[ \frac{q_0 \cos [\omega(t - \gr_+ / c)]}{\gr_+} - \frac{q_0 \cos[\omega(t - \gr_- / c)]}{\gr_-} \right] V ( r , t ) = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ [ γ + ​ q 0 ​ cos [ ω ( t − γ + ​ / c ) ] ​ − γ − ​ q 0 ​ cos [ ω ( t − γ − ​ / c ) ] ​ ] where γ ± = r 2 ∓ r d cos ⁡ θ + ( d / 2 ) 2 \gr_{\pm} = \sqrt{ r^2 \mp r d \cos \theta + (d/2)^2} γ ± ​ = r 2 ∓ r d cos θ + ( d / 2 ) 2 ​ To take this physical dipole towards a perfect dipole, we want d ≪ r while q 0 d = const. d \ll r \quad \text{ while } \quad q_0 d = \text{const.} d ≪ r while q 0 ​ d = const. docs.title: 11.1.1 Electric Dipole Radiation

docs.text: .katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 2.1: The Electric Field 2.1.1: Introduction The fundamental problem electrodynamics hopes to solve is this (Fig 2.1): We have some electric charges q 1 , q 2 , q 3 , … q_1, q_2, q_3, \ldots q 1 ​ , q 2 ​ , q 3 ​ , … (call them source charges ); what force do they exert on another charge, Q Q Q (call it the test charge )? The positions of the source charges are given (as functions of time); the trajectory of the test particle is to be calculated. In general, both the source charges and the test charge are in motion. The solution to this problem is facilitated by the principle of superposition, which states that the interaction between any two charges is completely unaffected by the presence of others. This means that to determine the force on Q, we can first compute the force F 1 \vec{F_1} F 1 ​ , due to q 1 q_1 q 1 ​ alone (ignoring all the others); then we compute the force F 2 \vec{F_2} F 2 ​ , due to q 2 q_2 q 2 ​ alone, and so in. Finally, we take the vector sum of all these individual forces: F = F 1 + F 2 + F 3 + … \vec{F} = \vec{F_1} + \vec{F_2} + \vec{F_3} + \ldots F = F 1 ​ + F 2 ​ + F 3 ​ + … Thus, if we can find the force on Q due to a single source charge q q q , we are, in principle, done (the rest is just a question of repeating the same operation over and over, and adding it all up) The principle of superposition may seem "obvious" to you, but it did not have to be so simple: if the electromagnetic force were proportional to the square of the total source charge, for instance, the principle of superposition would not hold, since ( q 1 + q 2 ) 2 ≠ q 1 2 + q 2 2 (q_1 + q_2)^2 \neq q_1 ^2 + q_2 ^2 ( q 1 ​ + q 2 ​ ) 2  ​ = q 1 2 ​ + q 2 2 ​ (there would be "cross terms" to consider). Superposition is not a logical necessity, but an experimental fact. Well, at first sight this looks very easy: Why don't I just write down the formula for the force on Q due to q, and be done with it? I could , and in Chapter 10 I shall, but you would be shocked to see it at this stage, for not only does the force on Q depend on the separation distance γ \gr γ between the charges (Fig 2.2), it also depends on both their velocities and on the acceleration of q q q . Moreover, it is not the position, velocity, and acceleration of q q q right now that matter: electromagnetic "news" travels at the speed of light, so what concerns Q is the position, velocity, and acceleration q had at some earlier time, when the message left. Therefore, in spite of the fact that the basic question ("What is the force on Q due to q?") is easy to state, it does not pay to confront it head on; rather, we shall go at it by stages. In the meantime, the theory we develop will allow for the solution of more subtle electromagnetic problems that do not present themselves in quite this simple format. To begin with, we shall consider the special case of electrostatics in which all the source charges are stationary (though the test charge may be moving). 2.1.2: Coulomb's Law What is the force on a test charge Q due to a single point charge q, that is at rest a distance γ \gr γ away? The answer (based on experiments) is given by Coulomb's Law : F = 1 4 π ϵ 0 q Q γ 2 γ ^ 2.1 (2.1) \vec{F} = \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0}\frac{q Q}{\gr^2} \vu{\vec{\gr}} \label{2.1} \tag{2.1} F = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ γ 2 q Q ​ γ ^ ​ 2 . 1 ( 2 . 1 ) The constant ϵ 0 \epsilon_0 ϵ 0 ​ is called (ludicrously) the permittivity of free space . In SI units, where force is in newtons (N), distance in meters (m), and charge in coulombs (C), ϵ 0 = 8.85 × 1 0 − 12 C 2 N ⋅ m 2 \epsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \frac{C^2}{N \cdot m ^2} ϵ 0 ​ = 8 . 8 5 × 1 0 − 1 2 N ⋅ m 2 C 2 ​ In words, the force is proportional to the product of the charges and inversely proportional to the square of the separation distance. As always (Sect 1.1.4), γ \vec{\gr} γ is the separation vector from r ′ \vec{r'} r ′ (the location of q) to r \vec{r} r (the location of Q): γ = r − r ′ \vec{\gr} = \vec{r} - \vec{r}' γ = r − r ′ γ \gr γ is its magnitude, and γ ^ \vu{\gr} γ ^ ​ is its direction. The force points along the line from q to Q; it is repulsive if q and Q have the same sign, and attractive if their signs are opposite. docs.text: The fundamental problem electrodynamics hopes to solve is this (Fig 2.1): We have some electric charges q 1 , q 2 , q 3 , … q_1, q_2, q_3, \ldots q 1 ​ , q 2 ​ , q 3 ​ , … (call them source charges ); what force do they exert on another charge, Q Q Q (call it the test charge )? The positions of the source charges are given (as functions of time); the trajectory of the test particle is to be calculated. In general, both the source charges and the test charge are in motion. The solution to this problem is facilitated by the principle of superposition, which states that the interaction between any two charges is completely unaffected by the presence of others. This means that to determine the force on Q, we can first compute the force F 1 \vec{F_1} F 1 ​ , due to q 1 q_1 q 1 ​ alone (ignoring all the others); then we compute the force F 2 \vec{F_2} F 2 ​ , due to q 2 q_2 q 2 ​ alone, and so in. Finally, we take the vector sum of all these individual forces: F = F 1 + F 2 + F 3 + … \vec{F} = \vec{F_1} + \vec{F_2} + \vec{F_3} + \ldots F = F 1 ​ + F 2 ​ + F 3 ​ + … Thus, if we can find the force on Q due to a single source charge q q q , we are, in principle, done (the rest is just a question of repeating the same operation over and over, and adding it all up) The principle of superposition may seem "obvious" to you, but it did not have to be so simple: if the electromagnetic force were proportional to the square of the total source charge, for instance, the principle of superposition would not hold, since ( q 1 + q 2 ) 2 ≠ q 1 2 + q 2 2 (q_1 + q_2)^2 \neq q_1 ^2 + q_2 ^2 ( q 1 ​ + q 2 ​ ) 2  ​ = q 1 2 ​ + q 2 2 ​ (there would be "cross terms" to consider). Superposition is not a logical necessity, but an experimental fact. Well, at first sight this looks very easy: Why don't I just write down the formula for the force on Q due to q, and be done with it? I could , and in Chapter 10 I shall, but you would be shocked to see it at this stage, for not only does the force on Q depend on the separation distance γ \gr γ between the charges (Fig 2.2), it also depends on both their velocities and on the acceleration of q q q . Moreover, it is not the position, velocity, and acceleration of q q q right now that matter: electromagnetic "news" travels at the speed of light, so what concerns Q is the position, velocity, and acceleration q had at some earlier time, when the message left. Therefore, in spite of the fact that the basic question ("What is the force on Q due to q?") is easy to state, it does not pay to confront it head on; rather, we shall go at it by stages. In the meantime, the theory we develop will allow for the solution of more subtle electromagnetic problems that do not present themselves in quite this simple format. To begin with, we shall consider the special case of electrostatics in which all the source charges are stationary (though the test charge may be moving).

.katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 2.2: Divergence and Curl of Electrostatic Fields 2.2.1 Field Lines, Flux, and Gauss' Law In principle, we are done with the subject of electrostatics. Eq. 2.8 tells us how to compute the field of a charge distribution, and Eq. 2.3 tells us what the force on a charge Q placed in this field will be. Unfortunately, as you may have discovered, the integrals involved in computing E can be formidable, even for reasonably simple charge distributions. Much of the rest of electrostatics is devoted to assembling a bag of tools and tricks for avoiding these integrals. It all begins with the divergence and curl of E . I shall calculate the divergence of E directly from Eq. 2.8 in section 2.2.2, but first I want to show you a more qualitative, and perhaps more illuminating, intuitive approach. Let's begin with the simplest possible case: a single point charge q , situated at the origin: E ( r ) = 1 4 π ϵ 0 q r 2 r ^ 2.10 (2.10) \vec{E}(\vec{r}) =  rac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0}  rac{q}{r^2} \vu{\vec{r}} 	ag{2.10} \label{2.10} E ( r ) = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ r 2 q ​ r ^ 2 . 1 0 ( 2 . 1 0 ) To get a "feel" for this field, I might sketch a few representative vectors, as in Fig. 2.12a. Because the field falls off like 1 / r 2 1/r^2 1 / r 2 , the vectors get shorter as you go farther away from the origin; they always point radially outward. But there is a nicer way to represent this field, and that's to connect up the arrows, to form field lines (Fig. 2.12b). You might think that I have thereby thrown away information about the strength of the field, which was contained in the length of the arrows. But actually I have not. The magnitude of the field is indicated by the density of the field lines: it's strong near the center where the field lines are close together, and weak farther out, where they are relatively far apart. In truth, the field-line diagram is deceptive, when I draw it on a two-dimensional surface, for the density of lines passing through a circle of radius r is the total number divided by the circumference ( n / 2 π r n / 2 \pi r n / 2 π r ), which goes like ( 1 / r ) (1/r) ( 1 / r ) , not ( 1 / r 2 ) (1/r^2) ( 1 / r 2 ) . But if you imagine the model in three dimensions (a pincushion with needles sticking out in all directions), then the density of lines is the total number divided by the area of the sphere ( n / 4 π r 2 ) (n/4 \pi r^2) ( n / 4 π r 2 ) , which does go like ( 1 / r 2 ) (1/r^2) ( 1 / r 2 ) . Such diagrams are also convenient for representing more complicated fields. Of course, the number of lines you draw depends on how lazy you are (and how sharp your pencil is), though you ought to include enough to get an accurate sense of the field, and you must be consistent: if q q q gets 8 lines, then 2 q 2q 2 q deserves 16. And you must space them fairly - they emanate from a point charge symmetrically in all directions. Field lines begin on positive charges and end on negative ones; they cannot simply terminate in midair, though they may extend out to infinity. Moreover, field lines can never cross - at the intersection the field would have two different directions at once! With all this in mind, it is easy to sketch the field of any simple configuration of point charges: Begin by drawing the lines in the neighborhood of each charge, and then connect them up or extend them to infinity (Figs. 2.13 and 2.14) In this model, the flux of E through a surface S, Φ E ≡ ∫ S E ⋅ d a 2.11 (2.11) \Phi_E \equiv \int _S \vec{E} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} \label{2.11} 	ag{2.11} Φ E ​ ≡ ∫ S ​ E ⋅ d a 2 . 1 1 ( 2 . 1 1 ) is a measure of the "number of lines" passing through S. I put this in quotes because of course we can only draw a representative sample of field lines - the total number would be infinite. But for a given sampling rate the flux is proportional to the number of lines drawn, because the field strength, remember, is proportional to the density of field lines (the number per unit area), and hence E ⋅ d a \vec{E} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} E ⋅ d a is proportional to the number of lines passing through the infinitesimal area d a \dd{\vec{a}} d a . (The dot product picks out the component of d a \dd{\vec{a}} d a along the direction of E , as indicated in Fig 2.15. It is the area in the plane perpendicular to E that we have in mind when we say that the density of field lines is the number per unit area). This suggests that the flux through any closed surface is a measure of the total charge inside. For the field lines that originate on a positive charge must either pass out through the surface or else terminate on a negative charge inside (Fig 2.16a).
