docs.text: The primary task of electrostatics is to find the electric field of a given stationary charge distribution. In principle, this purpose is accomplished by Coulomb's law, in the form of E ( r ) = 1 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ ρ ( r ′ ) γ 2 γ ^ d τ ′ 3.1 \vec{E}(\vec{r}) = \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \int \frac{\rho(\vec{r'})}{\gr ^2} \vu{\gr} \dd{\tau'} \label{3.1} E ( r ) = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ ∫ γ 2 ρ ( r ′ ) ​ γ ^ ​ d τ ′ 3 . 1 Unfortunately, integrals of this type can be difficult to calculate for any but the simplest charge configurations. Occasionally we can get around this by exploiting symmetry and using Gauss's law, but ordinarily the best strategy is first to calculate the potential , V, which is given by the somewhat more tractable V ( r ) = 1 4 π ϵ 0 ∫ ρ ( r ′ ) γ d τ ′ (3.2) V(r) = \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \int \frac{\rho(\vec{r}')}{\gr} \dd{\tau'} \tagl{3.2} V ( r ) = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ ∫ γ ρ ( r ′ ) ​ d τ ′ ( 3 . 2 ) Still, even this integral is often too tough to handle analytically. Moreover, in problems involving conductors ρ \rho ρ itself may not be known in advance; since charge is free to move around, the only thing we control directly is the total charge (or perhaps the potential) of each conductor. In such cases, it is fruitful to recast the problem in differential form, using Poisson's equation ∇ 2 V = − 1 ϵ 0 ρ 3.3 \laplacian{V} = - \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} \rho \label{3.3} ∇ 2 V = − ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ ρ 3 . 3 which, together with appropriate boundary conditions, is equivalent to ( 3.2 ) \eqref{3.2} ( 3 . 2 ) . Very often, in fact, we are interested in finding the potential in a region where ρ = 0 \rho = 0 ρ = 0 . (If ρ = 0 \rho = 0 ρ = 0 everywhere, of course, then V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 , and there is nothing further to say - that's not what I mean. There may be plenty of charge elsewhere, but we're confining our attention to places where there is no charge.) In this case, Poisson's equation reduces to Laplace's equation ∇ 2 V = 0 3.4 \laplacian{V} = 0 \label{3.4} ∇ 2 V = 0 3 . 4 or, written out in Cartesian coordinates, ∂ 2 V ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ y 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ z 2 = 0 3.5 \frac{\partial^2{V}}{\partial{x^2}} + \frac{\partial^2 V}{\partial{y^2}} + \frac{\partial^2{V}}{\partial{z^2}} = 0 \label{3.5} ∂ x 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ y 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ z 2 ∂ 2 V ​ = 0 3 . 5 This formula is so fundamental to the subject that one might almost say electrostatics is the study of Laplace's equation. At the same time, it is a ubiquitous equation, appearing in such diverse branches of physics as gravitation and magnetism, the theory of heat, and the study of soap bubbles. In mathematics, it plays a major role in analytic function theory. To get a feel for Laplace's equation and its solutions (which are called harmonic functions ), we shall begin with the one- and two-dimensional versions, which are easier to picture, and illustrate all the essential properties of the three-dimensional case.

docs.text: Suppose V depends on only one variable, x. Then Laplace's equation becomes d 2 V d x 2 = 0 \frac{d^2 V}{dx^2} = 0 d x 2 d 2 V ​ = 0 The general solution is V ( x ) = m x + b 3.6 (3.6) V(x) = mx + b \label{3.6} \tag{3.6} V ( x ) = m x + b 3 . 6 ( 3 . 6 ) the equation for a straight line. It contains two undetermined constants (m and b), as is appropriate for a second-order (ordinary) differential equation. They are fixed, in any particular case, by the boundary conditions of that problem. For instance, it might be specified that V = 4 V = 4 V = 4 at x = 1 x = 1 x = 1 and V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 at x = 5 x = 5 x = 5 . In that case, m = − 1 m = -1 m = − 1 and b = 5 b = 5 b = 5 , so V = − x + 5 V = - x + 5 V = − x + 5 (See Fig. 3.1) I want to call your attention to two features of this result; they may seem silly and obvious in one dimension, where I can write down the general solution explicitly, but the analogs in two and three dimensions are powerful and by no means obvious: V(x) is the average of V ( x + a ) V(x + a) V ( x + a ) and V ( x − a ) V(x - a) V ( x − a ) for any a: V ( x ) = 1 2 [ V ( x + a ) + V ( x − a ) ] V(x) = \frac{1}{2} [V(x + a) + V(x-a)] V ( x ) = 2 1 ​ [ V ( x + a ) + V ( x − a ) ] Laplace's equation is a kind of averaging instruction; it tells you to assign to the point x the average of the values to the left and to the right of x. Solutions to Laplace's equation are, in this sense, as boring as they could possibly be, and yet fit the end points properly. Laplace's equation tolerates no local maxima or minima ; extreme values of V must occur at the end points. Actually, this is a consequence of (1), for if there were a local maximum, V would be greater at that point than on either side, and therefore could not be the average. (Ordinarily, you expect the second derivative to be negative at a maximum and positive at a minimum. Since Laplace's equation requires, on the contrary, that the second derivative is zero, it seems reasonable that solutions should exhibit no extrema. However, this is not a proof, since there exist functions that have maxima and minima at points where the second derivative vanishes: x 4 x^4 x 4 for example, has such a minimum point at x = 0 x=0 x = 0 ).

Nevertheless, the same two properties remain true, and this time I will sketch a proof. Proof: V is a solution to the three-dimensional Laplace's equation. Then the value of V at point r is the average value of V over a spherical surface of radius R centered at r Let's begin by calculating the average potential over a spherical surface of radius R due to a single point charge q located outside the sphere. We may as well center the sphere at the origin and choose coordinates so that q lies on the z-axis (Fig 3.3). docs.title: 3.1.4: Laplace's Equation in Three Dimensions

docs.text: Laplace's equation does not by itself determine V; in addition, suitable boundary conditions must be supplied. This raises a delicate question: What are appropriate boundary conditions, sufficient to determine the answer and yet not so strong as to generate inconsistencies? The one-dimensional case is easy, for here the general solution V = m x + b V = mx + b V = m x + b contains two arbitrary constants, and we therefore require two boundary conditions. We might, for instance, specify the value of the function at each end, or we might give the value of the function and its derivative at one end, or the value at one end and the derivative at the other, and so on. But we cannot get away with just the value or just the derivative at one end - this is insufficient information. Nor would it do to specify the derivatives at both ends - this would be either redundant (if the two are equal) or inconsistent (if they are not). In two or three dimensions we are confronted by a partial differential equation, and it is not so obvious what would constitute acceptable boundary conditions. Is the shape of a taut rubber membrane, for instance, uniquely determined by the frame over which it is stretched, or, like a canning jar lid, can it snap from one stable configuration to another? The answer, as I think your intuition would suggest, that V is uniquely determined by its value at the boundary (canning jars evidently do not obey Laplace's equation). However, other boundary conditions can also be used (see Prob. 3.5). The proof that a proposed set of boundary conditions will suffice is usually presented in the form of a uniqueness theorem. There are many such theorems for electrostatics, all sharing the same basic format - I'll show you the two most useful ones: First Uniqueness Theorem: The solution to Laplace's equation in some volume V \mathscr{V} V is uniquely determined if V is specified on the boundary surface S \mathscr{S} S . In Fig. 3.5 I have drawn such a region and its boundary. (There could also be "islands" inside, so long as V is given on all their surfaces; also, the outer boundary could be at infinity, where V is ordinarily taken to be zero.) Proof : Suppose there were two solutions to Laplace's equation: ∇ 2 V 1 = 0 and ∇ 2 V 2 = 0 \laplacian{V_1} = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad \laplacian{V_2} = 0 ∇ 2 V 1 ​ = 0 and ∇ 2 V 2 ​ = 0 both of which assume the specified value on the surface. I want to prove that they must be equal. The trick is to look at their difference : V 3 ≡ V 1 − V 2 V_3 \equiv V_1 - V_2 V 3 ​ ≡ V 1 ​ − V 2 ​ This obeys Laplace's equation (obviously) ∇ 2 V 3 = ∇ 2 V 1 − ∇ 2 V 2 = 0 \laplacian{V_3} = \laplacian{V_1} - \laplacian{V_2} = 0 ∇ 2 V 3 ​ = ∇ 2 V 1 ​ − ∇ 2 V 2 ​ = 0 and it takes the value zero on all boundaries (since V 1 V_1 V 1 ​ and V 2 V_2 V 2 ​ are equal there). But Laplace's equation allows no local maxima or minima - all extrema occur on the boundaries. So the maximum and minimum of V 3 V_3 V 3 ​ are both zero. Therefore V 3 V_3 V 3 ​ must be zero everywhere, and hence V 1 = V 2 V_1 = V_2 V 1 ​ = V 2 ​

docs.text: Show that the potential is constant inside an enclosure completely surrounded by conducting material, provided there is no charge within the enclosure. Solution The potential on the cavity wall is some constant V 0 V_0 V 0 ​ (that's item (iv) in Sect. 2.5.1), so the potential inside is a function that satisfies Laplace's equation and has the constant value V 0 V_0 V 0 ​ at the boundary. It doesn't take a genius to think of one solution to this problem: V = V 0 V = V_0 V = V 0 ​ everywhere. The uniqueness theorem guarantees that this is the only solution. (It follows that the field inside an empty cavity is zero - the same result we found in Sect. 2.5.2 on rather different grounds.) The uniqueness theorem is a license to your imagination. It doesn't matter how you come by your solution; if (a) it satisfies Laplace's equation and (b) it has the correct value on the boundaries, then it's right . You'll see the power of this argument when we come to the method of images. Incidentally, it is easy to improve on the first uniqueness theorem: I assumed there was no charge inside the region in question, so the potential obeyed Laplace's equation, but we may as well throw in some charge (in which case V obeys Poisson's equation). docs.text: The simplest way to set the boundary conditions for an electrostatic problem is to specify the value of V on all surfaces surrounding the region of interest. And this situation often occurs in practice: In the laboratory, we have conductors connected to batteries, which maintain a given potential, or to ground , which is the experimentalist's word for V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 . However, there are other circumstances in which we do not know the potential at the boundary, but rather the charges on various conducting surfaces. Suppose I put Q a Q_a Q a ​ on the first conductor, Q b Q_b Q b ​ on the second conductor, and so on - I'm not telling you how the charge distributes itself over each conducting surface, because as soon as I put it on, it moves around in a way I do not control. And for good measure, let's say there is some specified charge density ρ \rho ρ in the region between the conductors. Is the electric field now uniquely determined? Or are there perhaps a number of different ways the charges could arrange themselves on their respective conductors, each leading to a different field? Second uniqueness theorem : In a volume V \mathscr{V} V surrounded by conductors and containing a specified charge density ρ \rho ρ , the electric field is uniquely determined if the total charge on each conductor is given (Fig. 3.6). (The region as a whole can be bounded by another conductor, or else unbounded.) Proof : Suppose there are two fields satisfying the conditions of the problem. Both obey Gauss's law in differential form in the space betwen the conductors: ∇ ⋅ E 1 = 1 ϵ 0 ρ , ∇ ⋅ E 2 = 1 ϵ 0 ρ \div{\vec{E_1}} = \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} \rho, \qquad \div{\vec{E_2}} = \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} \rho ∇ ⋅ E 1 ​ = ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ ρ , ∇ ⋅ E 2 ​ = ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ ρ And both obey Gauss's law in integral form for a Gaussian surface enclosing each conductor ∮ i t h conducting surface E 1 ⋅ d a = 1 ϵ 0 Q i and ∮ i t h conducting surface E 2 ⋅ d a = 1 ϵ 0 Q i and \oint_{i_{th} \text{ conducting surface}} \vec{E_1} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} = \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} Q_i \quad \text{ and } \\ \oint_{i_{th} \text{ conducting surface}} \vec{E_2} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} = \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} Q_i \quad \text{ and } \\ ∮ i t h ​ conducting surface ​ E 1 ​ ⋅ d a = ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ Q i ​ and ∮ i t h ​ conducting surface ​ E 2 ​ ⋅ d a = ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ Q i ​ and Likewise, for the outer boundary (whether this is just inside an enclosing conductor at infinity), ∮ outer boundary E 1 ⋅ d a = 1 ϵ 0 Q t o t ∮ outer boundary E 2 ⋅ d a = 1 ϵ 0 Q t o t \oint_{\text{outer boundary}} \vec{E_1} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} = \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} Q_{tot} \\ \oint_{\text{outer boundary}} \vec{E_2} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} = \frac{1}{\epsilon_0} Q_{tot} ∮ outer boundary ​ E 1 ​ ⋅ d a = ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ Q t o t ​ ∮ outer boundary ​ E 2 ​ ⋅ d a = ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ Q t o t ​ As before, we examine the difference E 3 ≡ E 1 − E 2 \vec{E_3} \equiv \vec{E_1} - \vec{E_2} E 3 ​ ≡ E 1 ​ − E 2 ​ which obeys ∇ ⋅ E 3 = 0 3.7 (3.7) \div{\vec{E_3}} = 0 \label{3.7} \tag{3.7} ∇ ⋅ E 3 ​ = 0 3 . 7 ( 3 . 7 ) in the region between the conductors, and ∮ E 3 ⋅ d a = 0 3.8 (3.8) \oint \vec{E_3} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} = 0 \label{3.8} \tag{3.8} ∮ E 3 ​ ⋅ d a = 0 3 . 8 ( 3 . 8 ) over each boundary surface. Now there is one final piece of information we must exploit: Although we do not know how the charge Q i Q_i Q i ​ distributes itself over the _i_th conductor, we do know that each conductor is an equipotential, and hence V 3 V_3 V 3 ​ is a constant (not necessarily the same constant) over each conducting surface. (It need not be zero, for the potentials V 1 V_1 V 1 ​ and V 2 V_2 V 2 ​ may not be equal - all we know for sure is that both are constant over any given conductor.) Next comes a trick. Invoking the product rule ∇ ⋅ ( V 3 E 3 ) = V 3 ( ∇ ⋅ E 3 ) + E 3 ⋅ ( ∇ V 3 ) = − ( E 3 ) 2 \div{(V_3 \vec{E_3})} = V_3 (\div{\vec{E_3}}) + \vec{E_3} \cdot (\grad{V_3}) = - (E_3)^2 ∇ ⋅ ( V 3 ​ E 3 ​ ) = V 3 ​ ( ∇ ⋅ E 3 ​ ) + E 3 ​ ⋅ ( ∇ V 3 ​ ) = − ( E 3 ​ ) 2 Here I have used ( 3.7 ) \eqref{3.7} ( 3 . 7 ) and E 3 = − ∇ V 3 \vec{E_3} = - \grad{V_3} E 3 ​ = − ∇ V 3 ​ . Integrating this over V \mathscr{V} V and applying the divergence theorem to the left side: ∫ V ∇ ⋅ ( V 3 E 3 ) d τ = ∮ S V 3 E 3 ⋅ d a = − ∫ V ( E 3 ) 2 d τ \int_{\mathscr{V}} \div{(V_3 \vec{E_3})} \dd{\tau} = \oint_{S} V_3 \vec{E_3} \cdot \dd{\vec{a}} = - \int_{\mathscr{V}} (E_3)^2 \dd{\tau} ∫ V ​ ∇ ⋅ ( V 3 ​ E 3 ​ ) d τ = ∮ S ​ V 3 ​ E 3 ​ ⋅ d a = − ∫ V ​ ( E 3 ​ ) 2 d τ The surface integral covers all boundaries of the region in question - the conductors and outer boundary. Now V 3 V_3 V 3 ​ is a constant over each surface (if the outer boundary is invinity, V 3 = 0 V_3 = 0 V 3 ​ = 0 there), so it comes outside each integral, and what remains is zero, according to ( 3.8 ) \eqref{3.8} ( 3 . 8 ) . Therefore ∫ V ( E 3 ) 2 d τ = 0 \int_{\mathscr{V}}(E_3)^2 \dd{\tau} = 0 ∫ V ​ ( E 3 ​ ) 2 d τ = 0 The integrand is never negative, so the only way the integral can vanish is if E 3 = 0 E_3 = 0 E 3 ​ = 0 everywhere. Consequently, E 1 = E 2 \vec{E_1} = \vec{E_2} E 1 ​ = E 2 ​ and the theorem is proved. This proof was not easy, and there is a real danger that the theorem itself will seem more plausible to you than the proof. In case you think the second uniqueness theorem is "obvious," consider this example of Purcell's: Figure 3.7 shows a simple electrostatic configuration, consisting of four conductors with charges ± Q \pm Q ± Q , situated so that the plusses are near the minuses. It all looks very comfortable. Now, what happens if we join them in pairs, by tiny wires, as indicated in Fig. 3.8? Since the positive charges are very near negative charges (which is where they like to be) you might well guess that nothing will happen - the configuration looks stable. Well, that sounds reasonable, but it's wrong. The configuration in Fig. 3.8 is impossible. For there are now effectively two conductors, and the total charge on each is zero. One possible way to distribute zero charge over these conductors is to have no accumulation of charge anywhere, and hence zero field everywhere (Fig. 3.9). By the second uniqueness theorem, this must be the solution: The charge will flow down the tiny wires, canceling itself off.

Question : what is the potential in the region above the plane? It's not just ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ) q / γ (1/4 \pi \epsilon_0) q / \gr ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ​ ) q / γ , for q will induce a certain amount of negative charge on the nearby surface of the conductor; the total potential is due in part to q directly, and in part to this induced charge. But how can we possibly calculate the potential, when we don't know how much charge is induced or how it is distributed? From a mathematical point of view, our problem is to solve Poisson's equation in the region z > 0 z > 0 z > 0 , with a single point charge q at ( 0 , 0 , d ) (0, 0, d) ( 0 , 0 , d ) , subject to the boundary conditions V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when z = 0 z = 0 z = 0 (since the conducting plane is grounded) V → 0 V \rightarrow 0 V → 0 far from the charge (that is, for x 2 + y 2 + z 2 ≫ d 2 x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \gg d^2 x 2 + y 2 + z 2 ≫ d 2 The first uniqueness theorem (actually, its corollary) guarantees that there is only one function that meets these requirements. If by trick or clever guess we can discover such a function, it's got to be the answer. Trick: Forget about the actual problem; we're going to study a completely different situation. This new configuration consists of two point charges, + q +q + q at ( 0 , 0 , d ) (0, 0, d) ( 0 , 0 , d ) and − q -q − q at ( 0 , 0 , − d ) (0, 0, -d) ( 0 , 0 , − d ) , and no conducting plane (Fig. 3.11). docs.text: Suppose a point charge q is held a distance d above an infinite grounded conducting plane (Fig. 3.10). Question : what is the potential in the region above the plane? It's not just ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ) q / γ (1/4 \pi \epsilon_0) q / \gr ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ​ ) q / γ , for q will induce a certain amount of negative charge on the nearby surface of the conductor; the total potential is due in part to q directly, and in part to this induced charge. But how can we possibly calculate the potential, when we don't know how much charge is induced or how it is distributed? From a mathematical point of view, our problem is to solve Poisson's equation in the region z > 0 z > 0 z > 0 , with a single point charge q at ( 0 , 0 , d ) (0, 0, d) ( 0 , 0 , d ) , subject to the boundary conditions V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when z = 0 z = 0 z = 0 (since the conducting plane is grounded) V → 0 V \rightarrow 0 V → 0 far from the charge (that is, for x 2 + y 2 + z 2 ≫ d 2 x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \gg d^2 x 2 + y 2 + z 2 ≫ d 2 The first uniqueness theorem (actually, its corollary) guarantees that there is only one function that meets these requirements. If by trick or clever guess we can discover such a function, it's got to be the answer. Trick: Forget about the actual problem; we're going to study a completely different situation. This new configuration consists of two point charges, + q +q + q at ( 0 , 0 , d ) (0, 0, d) ( 0 , 0 , d ) and − q -q − q at ( 0 , 0 , − d ) (0, 0, -d) ( 0 , 0 , − d ) , and no conducting plane (Fig. 3.11). For this configuration I can easily write down the potential: V ( x , y , z ) = 1 4 π ϵ 0 [ q x 2 + y 2 + ( z − d ) 2 − q x 2 + y 2 + ( z + d ) 2 ] 3.9 (3.9) V(x, y, z) = \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_0} \left[ \frac{q}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + (z - d)^2 }} - \frac{q}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + (z + d)^2}} \right] \label{3.9} \tag{3.9} V ( x , y , z ) = 4 π ϵ 0 ​ 1 ​ [ x 2 + y 2 + ( z − d ) 2 ​ q ​ − x 2 + y 2 + ( z + d ) 2 ​ q ​ ] 3 . 9 ( 3 . 9 ) It follows that V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when z = 0 z = 0 z = 0 V → 0 V \rightarrow 0 V → 0 for x 2 + y 2 + z 2 ≫ d 2 x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \gg d^2 x 2 + y 2 + z 2 ≫ d 2 and the only charge in the region z > 0 z > 0 z > 0 is the point charge + q +q + q at ( 0 , 0 , d ) (0, 0, d) ( 0 , 0 , d ) . But these are precisely the conditions of the original problem! Evidently the second configuration happens to produce exactly the same potential as the first configuration, in the "upper" region z ≥ 0 z \geq 0 z ≥ 0 . (The "lower" region, z < 0 z < 0 z < 0 , is completely different, but who cares? The upper part is all we need.) Conclusion : The potential of a point charge above an infinite grounded conductor is given by ( 3.9 ) \eqref{3.9} ( 3 . 9 ) , for z > 0 z > 0 z > 0 . Notice the crucial role played by the uniqueness theorem in this argument: without it, no one would believe this solution, since it was obtained for a completely different charge distribution. But the uniqueness theorem certifies it: If it satisfies Poisson's equation in the region of interest, and assumes the correct value at the boundaries, then it must be right.

docs.text: The method just described is not limited to a single point charge; any stationary charge distribution near a grounded conducting plane can be treated in the same way, by introducing its mirror image - hence the name method of images. (Remember that the image charges have the opposite sign; this is what guarantees that the xy plane will be at potential zero.) There are also some exotic problems that can be handled in similar fashion; the nicest of these is the following.

docs.text: .katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 3.3: Separation of Variables In this section we shall attack Laplace's equation directly, using the method of separation of variables , which is the physicist's favorite tool for solving partial differential equations. The method is applicable in circumstances where the potential ( V ) (V) ( V ) or the charge density ( σ ) (\sigma) ( σ ) is specified on the boundaries of some region, and we are asked to find the potential in the interior. The basic strategy is very simple: We look for solutions that are products of functions, each of which depends on only one of the coordinates. The algebraic details, however, can be formidable, so I'm going to develop the method through a sequence of examples. We'll start with Cartesian coordinates and then do spherical coordinates (I'll leave the cylindrical case for you to tackle on your own, in Prob 3.24). 3.3.1: Cartesian Coordinates Example 3.3 Two infinite grounded metal plates lie parallel to the xz plane, one at y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 , the other at y = a y = a y = a (Fig. 3.17). The left end, at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 , is closed off with an infinite strip insulated from the two plates, and maintained at a specific potential V 0 ( y ) V_0(y) V 0 ​ ( y ) . Find the potential inside this 'slot.' Solution The configuration is independent of z, so this is really a two-dimensional problem. In mathematical terms, we must solve Laplace's equation, ∂ 2 V ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ y 2 = 0 3.20 (3.20) \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{x^2}} + \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{y^2}} = 0 \label{3.20} \tag{3.20} ∂ x 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ y 2 ∂ 2 V ​ = 0 3 . 2 0 ( 3 . 2 0 ) subject to the boundary conditions (i) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 (ii) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = a y = a y = a (iii) V = V 0 ( y ) V = V_0(y) V = V 0 ​ ( y ) when x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 (iv) V → 0 V \rightarrow 0 V → 0 as x → ∞ x \rightarrow \infty x → ∞ (The latter, although not explicitly stated in the problem, is necessary on physical grounds: as you get farther and farther away from the "hot" strip at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 , the potential should drop to zero.) Since the potential is specified on all boundaries, the answer is uniquely determined. The first step is to look for solutions in the form of products: V ( x , y ) = X ( x ) Y ( y ) (3.22) V(x, y) = X(x)Y(y) \tagl{3.22} V ( x , y ) = X ( x ) Y ( y ) ( 3 . 2 2 ) On the face of it, this is an absurd restriction - the overwhelming majority of solutions to Laplace's equation do not have such a form. For example, V ( x , y ) = ( 5 x + 6 y ) V(x, y) = (5x + 6y) V ( x , y ) = ( 5 x + 6 y ) satisfies the equation, but you can't express it as the product of a function of x times a function of y. Obviously, we're only going to get a tiny subset of all possible solutions by this means, and it would be a miracle if one of them happened to fit the boundary conditions of our problem... But hang on, because the solutions we do get are very special, and it turns out that by pasting them together we can construct the general solution. Anyway, putting ( 3.22 ) \eqref{3.22} ( 3 . 2 2 ) into ( 3.20 ) \eqref{3.20} ( 3 . 2 0 ) we obtain Y d 2 X d x 2 + X d 2 Y d y 2 = 0 Y \frac{d^2X}{dx^2} + X \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = 0 Y d x 2 d 2 X ​ + X d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = 0 The next step is to "separate the variables" (that is, collect all the x-dependence into one term and all the y-dependence into another). Typically, this is accomplished by dividing through by V: 1 X d 2 X d x 2 + 1 Y d 2 Y d y 2 = 0 (3.23) \frac{1}{X} \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} + \frac{1}{Y} \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = 0 \tagl{3.23} X 1 ​ d x 2 d 2 X ​ + Y 1 ​ d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = 0 ( 3 . 2 3 ) Here the first term depends only on x and the second term only on y; in other words, we have an equation of the form f ( x ) + g ( y ) = 0 3.24 (3.24) f(x) + g(y) = 0 \label{3.24} \tag{3.24} f ( x ) + g ( y ) = 0 3 . 2 4 ( 3 . 2 4 ) Now, there's only one way this could possibly be true: f and g must both be constant . For what if f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) changed, as you vary x - then if we held y fixed and fiddled with x, the sum f ( x ) + g ( y ) f(x) + g(y) f ( x ) + g ( y ) would change, in violation of ( 3.24 ) \eqref{3.24} ( 3 . 2 4 ) , which says it's always zero. (That's a simple but somehow rather elusive argument; don't accept it without due thought, because the whole method rides on it.) It follows from ( 3.23 ) \eqref{3.23} ( 3 . 2 3 ) , then, that 1 X d 2 X d x 2 = C 1 and 1 Y d 2 Y d y 2 = C 2 , with C 1 + C 2 = 0 (3.25) \frac{1}{X} \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} = C_1 \quad \text{ and } \quad \frac{1}{Y} \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = C_2, \quad \text{ with } C_1 + C_2 = 0 \tagl{3.25} X 1 ​ d x 2 d 2 X ​ = C 1 ​ and Y 1 ​ d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = C 2 ​ , with C 1 ​ + C 2 ​ = 0 ( 3 . 2 5 ) One of these constants is positive, the other negative (or perhaps both are zero). In general, one must investigate all possibilities; however in our particular problem we need C 1 C_1 C 1 ​ positive and C 2 C_2 C 2 ​ negative, for reasons that will appear in a moment. Thus d 2 X d x 2 = k 2 X , d 2 Y d y 2 = − k 2 Y (3.26) \frac{d^2X}{dx^2} = k^2 X, \qquad \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = - k^2 Y \tagl{3.26} d x 2 d 2 X ​ = k 2 X , d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = − k 2 Y ( 3 . 2 6 ) Notice what has happened: A partial differential equation has been converted into two ordinary differential equations. The advantage of this is obvious - ordinary differential equations are a lot easier to solve. Indeed: X ( x ) = A e k t + B e − k t , Y ( y ) = C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y X(x) = A e^{kt} + B e^{-kt}, \qquad Y(y) = C \sin ky + D \cos ky X ( x ) = A e k t + B e − k t , Y ( y ) = C sin k y + D cos k y so V ( x , y ) = ( A e k t + B e − k t ) ( C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y ) (3.27) V(x, y) = (A e^{kt} + B e^{-kt})(C \sin ky + D \cos ky) \tagl{3.27} V ( x , y ) = ( A e k t + B e − k t ) ( C sin k y + D cos k y ) ( 3 . 2 7 ) This is the appropriate separable solution to Laplace's equation; it remains to impose the boundary conditions, and see what they tell us about the constants. To begin at the end, condition (iv) requires tha A equal zero. Absorbing B into C and D, we are left with V ( x , y ) = e − k x ( C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y ) V(x, y) = e^{-kx} (C\sin ky + D \cos ky) V ( x , y ) = e − k x ( C sin k y + D cos k y ) Condition (i) now demands that D equal zero V ( x , y ) = C − k x sin ⁡ k y (3.28) V(x, y) = C ^{-kx} \sin ky \tagl{3.28} V ( x , y ) = C − k x sin k y ( 3 . 2 8 ) Meanwhile (ii) yields sin ⁡ k a = 0 \sin ka = 0 sin k a = 0 , from which it follows that k = n π a ( n = 1 , 2 , 3 , … ) (3.29) k = \frac{n \pi}{a} \quad (n = 1, 2, 3, \ldots) \tagl{3.29} k = a n π ​ ( n = 1 , 2 , 3 , … ) ( 3 . 2 9 ) (At this point you can see why I chose C 1 C_1 C 1 ​ positive and C 2 C_2 C 2 ​ negative: If X were sinusoidal, we could never manage for it to go to zero at infinity, and if Y were exponential we could not make it vanish at both 0 and a . Incidentally, n = 0 n = 0 n = 0 is no good, for in that case the potential vanishes everywhere. And we have already excluded negative n's) That's as far as we can go, using separable solutions, and unless V 0 ( y ) V_0(y) V 0 ​ ( y ) just happens to have the form sin ⁡ ( n π / a ) \sin(n \pi / a) sin ( n π / a ) for some integer n , we simply can't fit the final boundary condition at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 . But now comes the crucial step that redeems the method: Separation of variables has given us an infinite family of solutions (one for each n), and whereas none of them by itself satisfies the final boundary condition, it is possible to combine them in a way that does . Laplace's equation is linear, in the sense that if V 1 , V 2 , V 3 , … V_1, V_2, V_3, \ldots V 1 ​ , V 2 ​ , V 3 ​ , … satisfy it, so does any linear combination, for ∇ 2 V = α 1 ∇ 2 V 1 + α 2 ∇ 2 V 2 + … = 0 α 1 + 0 α 2 + … = 0 \laplacian{V} = \alpha_1 \laplacian{V_1} + \alpha_2 \laplacian{V_2} + \ldots = 0 \alpha_1 + 0 \alpha_2 + \ldots = 0 ∇ 2 V = α 1 ​ ∇ 2 V 1 ​ + α 2 ​ ∇ 2 V 2 ​ + … = 0 α 1 ​ + 0 α 2 ​ + … = 0 Exploiting this fact, we can patch together the separable solutions ( 3.28 ) \eqref{3.28} ( 3 . 2 8 ) to construct a much more general solution: V ( x , y ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ C n e − n π x / a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) (3.30) V(x, y) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} C_n e^{-n \pi x / a} \sin (n \pi y / a) \tagl{3.30} V ( x , y ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n ​ e − n π x / a sin ( n π y / a ) ( 3 . 3 0 ) This still satisfies three of the boundary conditions; the question is, can we (by astute choice of the coefficients C n C_n C n ​ ) fit the final boundary condition (iii)? V ( 0 , y ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ C n sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) = V 0 ( y ) (3.31) V(0, y) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} C_n \sin (n \pi y / a) = V_0(y) \tagl{3.31} V ( 0 , y ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n ​ sin ( n π y / a ) = V 0 ​ ( y ) ( 3 . 3 1 ) Well, you may recognize this sum - it's a Fourier sine series. And Dirichlet's theorem guarantees that virtually any function V 0 ( y ) V_0(y) V 0 ​ ( y ) - it can even have a finite number of discontinuities - can be expanded in such a series. docs.title: 3.3 - Separation of Variables

docs.text: In this section we shall attack Laplace's equation directly, using the method of separation of variables , which is the physicist's favorite tool for solving partial differential equations. The method is applicable in circumstances where the potential ( V ) (V) ( V ) or the charge density ( σ ) (\sigma) ( σ ) is specified on the boundaries of some region, and we are asked to find the potential in the interior. The basic strategy is very simple: We look for solutions that are products of functions, each of which depends on only one of the coordinates. The algebraic details, however, can be formidable, so I'm going to develop the method through a sequence of examples. We'll start with Cartesian coordinates and then do spherical coordinates (I'll leave the cylindrical case for you to tackle on your own, in Prob 3.24).
docs.title: 3.3: Separation of Variables

docs.text: Two infinite grounded metal plates lie parallel to the xz plane, one at y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 , the other at y = a y = a y = a (Fig. 3.17). The left end, at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 , is closed off with an infinite strip insulated from the two plates, and maintained at a specific potential V 0 ( y ) V_0(y) V 0 ​ ( y ) . Find the potential inside this 'slot.' Solution The configuration is independent of z, so this is really a two-dimensional problem. In mathematical terms, we must solve Laplace's equation, ∂ 2 V ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ y 2 = 0 3.20 (3.20) \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{x^2}} + \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{y^2}} = 0 \label{3.20} \tag{3.20} ∂ x 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ y 2 ∂ 2 V ​ = 0 3 . 2 0 ( 3 . 2 0 ) subject to the boundary conditions (i) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 (ii) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = a y = a y = a (iii) V = V 0 ( y ) V = V_0(y) V = V 0 ​ ( y ) when x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 (iv) V → 0 V \rightarrow 0 V → 0 as x → ∞ x \rightarrow \infty x → ∞ (The latter, although not explicitly stated in the problem, is necessary on physical grounds: as you get farther and farther away from the "hot" strip at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 , the potential should drop to zero.) Since the potential is specified on all boundaries, the answer is uniquely determined. The first step is to look for solutions in the form of products: V ( x , y ) = X ( x ) Y ( y ) (3.22) V(x, y) = X(x)Y(y) \tagl{3.22} V ( x , y ) = X ( x ) Y ( y ) ( 3 . 2 2 ) On the face of it, this is an absurd restriction - the overwhelming majority of solutions to Laplace's equation do not have such a form. For example, V ( x , y ) = ( 5 x + 6 y ) V(x, y) = (5x + 6y) V ( x , y ) = ( 5 x + 6 y ) satisfies the equation, but you can't express it as the product of a function of x times a function of y. Obviously, we're only going to get a tiny subset of all possible solutions by this means, and it would be a miracle if one of them happened to fit the boundary conditions of our problem... But hang on, because the solutions we do get are very special, and it turns out that by pasting them together we can construct the general solution. Anyway, putting ( 3.22 ) \eqref{3.22} ( 3 . 2 2 ) into ( 3.20 ) \eqref{3.20} ( 3 . 2 0 ) we obtain Y d 2 X d x 2 + X d 2 Y d y 2 = 0 Y \frac{d^2X}{dx^2} + X \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = 0 Y d x 2 d 2 X ​ + X d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = 0 The next step is to "separate the variables" (that is, collect all the x-dependence into one term and all the y-dependence into another). Typically, this is accomplished by dividing through by V: 1 X d 2 X d x 2 + 1 Y d 2 Y d y 2 = 0 (3.23) \frac{1}{X} \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} + \frac{1}{Y} \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = 0 \tagl{3.23} X 1 ​ d x 2 d 2 X ​ + Y 1 ​ d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = 0 ( 3 . 2 3 ) Here the first term depends only on x and the second term only on y; in other words, we have an equation of the form f ( x ) + g ( y ) = 0 3.24 (3.24) f(x) + g(y) = 0 \label{3.24} \tag{3.24} f ( x ) + g ( y ) = 0 3 . 2 4 ( 3 . 2 4 ) Now, there's only one way this could possibly be true: f and g must both be constant . For what if f ( x ) f(x) f ( x ) changed, as you vary x - then if we held y fixed and fiddled with x, the sum f ( x ) + g ( y ) f(x) + g(y) f ( x ) + g ( y ) would change, in violation of ( 3.24 ) \eqref{3.24} ( 3 . 2 4 ) , which says it's always zero. (That's a simple but somehow rather elusive argument; don't accept it without due thought, because the whole method rides on it.) It follows from ( 3.23 ) \eqref{3.23} ( 3 . 2 3 ) , then, that 1 X d 2 X d x 2 = C 1 and 1 Y d 2 Y d y 2 = C 2 , with C 1 + C 2 = 0 (3.25) \frac{1}{X} \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} = C_1 \quad \text{ and } \quad \frac{1}{Y} \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = C_2, \quad \text{ with } C_1 + C_2 = 0 \tagl{3.25} X 1 ​ d x 2 d 2 X ​ = C 1 ​ and Y 1 ​ d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = C 2 ​ , with C 1 ​ + C 2 ​ = 0 ( 3 . 2 5 ) One of these constants is positive, the other negative (or perhaps both are zero). In general, one must investigate all possibilities; however in our particular problem we need C 1 C_1 C 1 ​ positive and C 2 C_2 C 2 ​ negative, for reasons that will appear in a moment. Thus d 2 X d x 2 = k 2 X , d 2 Y d y 2 = − k 2 Y (3.26) \frac{d^2X}{dx^2} = k^2 X, \qquad \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = - k^2 Y \tagl{3.26} d x 2 d 2 X ​ = k 2 X , d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = − k 2 Y ( 3 . 2 6 ) Notice what has happened: A partial differential equation has been converted into two ordinary differential equations. The advantage of this is obvious - ordinary differential equations are a lot easier to solve. Indeed: X ( x ) = A e k t + B e − k t , Y ( y ) = C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y X(x) = A e^{kt} + B e^{-kt}, \qquad Y(y) = C \sin ky + D \cos ky X ( x ) = A e k t + B e − k t , Y ( y ) = C sin k y + D cos k y so V ( x , y ) = ( A e k t + B e − k t ) ( C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y ) (3.27) V(x, y) = (A e^{kt} + B e^{-kt})(C \sin ky + D \cos ky) \tagl{3.27} V ( x , y ) = ( A e k t + B e − k t ) ( C sin k y + D cos k y ) ( 3 . 2 7 ) This is the appropriate separable solution to Laplace's equation; it remains to impose the boundary conditions, and see what they tell us about the constants. To begin at the end, condition (iv) requires tha A equal zero. Absorbing B into C and D, we are left with V ( x , y ) = e − k x ( C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y ) V(x, y) = e^{-kx} (C\sin ky + D \cos ky) V ( x , y ) = e − k x ( C sin k y + D cos k y ) Condition (i) now demands that D equal zero V ( x , y ) = C − k x sin ⁡ k y (3.28) V(x, y) = C ^{-kx} \sin ky \tagl{3.28} V ( x , y ) = C − k x sin k y ( 3 . 2 8 ) Meanwhile (ii) yields sin ⁡ k a = 0 \sin ka = 0 sin k a = 0 , from which it follows that k = n π a ( n = 1 , 2 , 3 , … ) (3.29) k = \frac{n \pi}{a} \quad (n = 1, 2, 3, \ldots) \tagl{3.29} k = a n π ​ ( n = 1 , 2 , 3 , … ) ( 3 . 2 9 ) (At this point you can see why I chose C 1 C_1 C 1 ​ positive and C 2 C_2 C 2 ​ negative: If X were sinusoidal, we could never manage for it to go to zero at infinity, and if Y were exponential we could not make it vanish at both 0 and a . Incidentally, n = 0 n = 0 n = 0 is no good, for in that case the potential vanishes everywhere. And we have already excluded negative n's) That's as far as we can go, using separable solutions, and unless V 0 ( y ) V_0(y) V 0 ​ ( y ) just happens to have the form sin ⁡ ( n π / a ) \sin(n \pi / a) sin ( n π / a ) for some integer n , we simply can't fit the final boundary condition at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 . But now comes the crucial step that redeems the method: Separation of variables has given us an infinite family of solutions (one for each n), and whereas none of them by itself satisfies the final boundary condition, it is possible to combine them in a way that does . Laplace's equation is linear, in the sense that if V 1 , V 2 , V 3 , … V_1, V_2, V_3, \ldots V 1 ​ , V 2 ​ , V 3 ​ , … satisfy it, so does any linear combination, for ∇ 2 V = α 1 ∇ 2 V 1 + α 2 ∇ 2 V 2 + … = 0 α 1 + 0 α 2 + … = 0 \laplacian{V} = \alpha_1 \laplacian{V_1} + \alpha_2 \laplacian{V_2} + \ldots = 0 \alpha_1 + 0 \alpha_2 + \ldots = 0 ∇ 2 V = α 1 ​ ∇ 2 V 1 ​ + α 2 ​ ∇ 2 V 2 ​ + … = 0 α 1 ​ + 0 α 2 ​ + … = 0 Exploiting this fact, we can patch together the separable solutions ( 3.28 ) \eqref{3.28} ( 3 . 2 8 ) to construct a much more general solution: V ( x , y ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ C n e − n π x / a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) (3.30) V(x, y) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} C_n e^{-n \pi x / a} \sin (n \pi y / a) \tagl{3.30} V ( x , y ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n ​ e − n π x / a sin ( n π y / a ) ( 3 . 3 0 ) This still satisfies three of the boundary conditions; the question is, can we (by astute choice of the coefficients C n C_n C n ​ ) fit the final boundary condition (iii)? V ( 0 , y ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ C n sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) = V 0 ( y ) (3.31) V(0, y) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} C_n \sin (n \pi y / a) = V_0(y) \tagl{3.31} V ( 0 , y ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n ​ sin ( n π y / a ) = V 0 ​ ( y ) ( 3 . 3 1 ) Well, you may recognize this sum - it's a Fourier sine series. And Dirichlet's theorem guarantees that virtually any function V 0 ( y ) V_0(y) V 0 ​ ( y ) - it can even have a finite number of discontinuities - can be expanded in such a series. But how do we actually determine the coefficients C n C_n C n ​ , buried as they are in that infinite sum? The device for accomplishing this is so lovely it deserves a name - I call it Fourier's trick , though it seems Euler had used essentially the same idea somewhat earlier. Here's how it goes: Multiply ( 3.31 ) \eqref{3.31} ( 3 . 3 1 ) by sin ⁡ ( n ′ π y / a ) \sin(n' \pi y /a) sin ( n ′ π y / a ) (where n ′ n' n ′ is a positive integer), and integrate from 0 to a: ∑ n = 1 ∞ C n ∫ 0 a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( n ′ π y / a ) d y = ∫ 0 a V 0 ( y ) sin ⁡ ( n ′ π / a ) d y (3.32) \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} C_n \int_{0} ^{a} \sin(n \pi y / a) \sin(n' \pi y/a) \dd{y} = \int_{0} ^a V_0(y) \sin (n' \pi /a) \dd{y} \tagl{3.32} n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n ​ ∫ 0 a ​ sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( n ′ π y / a ) d y = ∫ 0 a ​ V 0 ​ ( y ) sin ( n ′ π / a ) d y ( 3 . 3 2 ) You can work out the integral on the left yourself; the answer is ∫ 0 a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( n ′ π y / a ) d y = { 0 if n ′ ≠ n a 2 if n ′ = n (3.33) \int_{0} ^a \sin (n \pi y /a) \sin (n' \pi y / a) \dd{y} = \begin{cases} 0 & \quad \text{if } n' \neq n \\ \frac{a}{2} & \quad \text{if } n' = n \end{cases} \tagl{3.33} ∫ 0 a ​ sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( n ′ π y / a ) d y = { 0 2 a ​ ​ if n ′  ​ = n if n ′ = n ​ ( 3 . 3 3 ) Thus all the terms in the series drop out, save only the one where n = n ′ n = n' n = n ′ , and the left side of ( 3.32 ) \eqref{3.32} ( 3 . 3 2 ) reduces to ( a / 2 ) C n ′ (a/2)C_{n'} ( a / 2 ) C n ′ ​ . Conclusion : C n = 2 a ∫ 0 a V 0 ( y ) sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) d y (3.34) C_n = \frac{2}{a} \int_{0}^a V_0(y) \sin (n \pi y /a) \dd{y} \tagl{3.34} C n ​ = a 2 ​ ∫ 0 a ​ V 0 ​ ( y ) sin ( n π y / a ) d y ( 3 . 3 4 ) That does it: ( 3.30 ) \eqref{3.30} ( 3 . 3 0 ) is the solution, with coefficients given by e q r e f 3.34 eqref{3.34} e q r e f 3 . 3 4 . As a concrete example, suppose the strip at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 is a metal plate with constant potential V 0 V_0 V 0 ​ (remember, it's insulated from the grounded plates at y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 and y = a y = a y = a . Then C n = 2 V 0 a ∫ 0 a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) d y = 2 V 0 n π ( 1 − cos ⁡ n π ) = { 0 if n is even 4 V 0 n π if n is odd (3.35) C_n = \frac{2V_0}{a} \int_0 ^a \sin (n \pi y / a) \dd y \\ = \frac{2 V_0}{n \pi} (1 - \cos n \pi) = \begin{cases} 0 & \quad \text{if n is even } \\ \frac{4 V_0}{n \pi} & \quad \text{if n is odd} \end{cases} \tagl{3.35} C n ​ = a 2 V 0 ​ ​ ∫ 0 a ​ sin ( n π y / a ) d y = n π 2 V 0 ​ ​ ( 1 − cos n π ) = { 0 n π 4 V 0 ​ ​ ​ if n is even if n is odd ​ ( 3 . 3 5 ) Thus V ( x , y ) = 4 V 0 π ∑ n = 1 , 3 , 5 , … 1 n e − n π x / a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) (3.36) V(x, y) = \frac{4 V_0}{\pi} \sum_{n = 1, 3, 5, \ldots} \frac{1}{n} e^{- n \pi x / a} \sin (n \pi y / a) \tagl{3.36} V ( x , y ) = π 4 V 0 ​ ​ n = 1 , 3 , 5 , … ∑ ​ n 1 ​ e − n π x / a sin ( n π y / a ) ( 3 . 3 6 ) Figure 3.18 is a plot of this potential; Fig. 3.10 shows how the first few terms in the Fourier series combine to make a better and better approximation to the constant V 0 V_0 V 0 ​ : (a) is the n = 1 n=1 n = 1 term only, (b) includes n up to 5, (c) is the sum of the first 10 terms, and (d) is the sum of the first 100 terms. Incidentally, the infinite series in Eq. 3.36 can be summed explicitly (try your hand at it if you like); the result is V ( x , y ) = 2 V 0 π tan ⁡ − 1 ( sin ⁡ ( π y / a ) sinh ⁡ ( π x / a ) ) (3.37) V(x, y) = \frac{2V_0}{\pi} \tan^{-1} \left( \frac{\sin(\pi y / a)}{\sinh(\pi x /a )} \right) \tagl{3.37} V ( x , y ) = π 2 V 0 ​ ​ tan − 1 ( sinh ( π x / a ) sin ( π y / a ) ​ ) ( 3 . 3 7 ) In this form, it is easy to check that Laplace's equation is obeyed and the four boundary conditions are satisfied The success of this method hinged on two extraordinary properties of the separable solutions ( 3.28 ) \eqref{3.28} ( 3 . 2 8 ) and ( 3.29 ) \eqref{3.29} ( 3 . 2 9 ) : completeness and orthogonality . A set of functions f n ( y ) f_n(y) f n ​ ( y ) is said to be complete if any other function f ( y ) f(y) f ( y ) can be expressed as a linear combination of them: f ( y ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ C n f n ( y ) (3.38) f(y) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} C_n f_n(y) \tagl{3.38} f ( y ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n ​ f n ​ ( y ) ( 3 . 3 8 ) The functions sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) \sin (n \pi y/a) sin ( n π y / a ) are complete on the interval 0 ≤ y ≤ a 0 \leq y \leq a 0 ≤ y ≤ a . It was this fact, guaranteed by Dirichlet's theorem, that assured us ( 3.31 ) \eqref{3.31} ( 3 . 3 1 ) could be satisfied, given the proper choice of the coefficients C n C_n C n ​ . (The proof of completeness, for a particular set of functions, is an extremely difficult business, and I'm afraid physicists tend to assume it's true and leave the checking to others.) A set of functions is orthogonal if the integral of the product of any two different members of the set is zero: ∫ 0 a f n ( y ) f n ′ ( y ) d y = 0 for n ′ ≠ n \int_0 ^a f_n(y) f_{n'} (y) \dd{y} = 0 \quad \text{for } n' \neq n ∫ 0 a ​ f n ​ ( y ) f n ′ ​ ( y ) d y = 0 for n ′  ​ = n The sine functions are orthogonal ( 3.33 ) \eqref{3.33} ( 3 . 3 3 ) ; that is the property on which Fourier's trick is based, allowing us to kill off all terms but one in the infinite series and thereby solve for the coefficients C n C_n C n ​ (Proof of orthogonality is generally quite simple, either by direct integration or by analysis of the differential equation from which the functions came.)

docs.text: Two infinitely-long grounded metal plates, again at y = 0 y=0 y = 0 and y = a y=a y = a are connected at x = ± b x= \pm b x = ± b by metal strips maintained at a constant potential V 0 V_0 V 0 ​ , as shown in Fig. 3.20 (a thin layer of insulation at each corner prevents them from shorting out). Find the potential inside the resulting rectangular pipe. Solution Once again, the configuration is independent of z. Our problem is to solve Laplace's equation ∂ 2 V ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ y 2 = 0 \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{x^2}} + \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{y^2}} = 0 ∂ x 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ y 2 ∂ 2 V ​ = 0 subject to the boundary conditions (i) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 (ii) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = a y = a y = a (iii) V = V 0 V = V_0 V = V 0 ​ when x = b x = b x = b (iv) V = V 0 V = V_0 V = V 0 ​ when x = − b x = -b x = − b The argument runs as before, up to ( 3.27 ) \eqref{3.27} ( 3 . 2 7 ) : V ( x , y ) = ( A e k t + B e − k t ) ( C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y ) V(x, y) = (A e^{kt} + B e^{-kt})(C \sin ky + D \cos ky) V ( x , y ) = ( A e k t + B e − k t ) ( C sin k y + D cos k y ) This time, however, we cannot set A = 0 A = 0 A = 0 ; the region in question does not extend to x = ∞ x = \infty x = ∞ , so e k x e^{kx} e k x is perfectly acceptable. On the other hand, the situation is symmetric with respect to x, so V ( − x , y ) = V ( x , y ) V(-x, y) = V(x, y) V ( − x , y ) = V ( x , y ) , and it follows that A = B A = B A = B . Using e k x + e − k x = 2 cosh ⁡ k x e^{kx} + e^{-kx} = 2 \cosh kx e k x + e − k x = 2 cosh k x and absorbing 2 A 2A 2 A into C C C and D D D , we have V ( x , y ) = cosh ⁡ k x ( C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y ) V(x, y) = \cosh kx (C \sin ky + D\cos ky) V ( x , y ) = cosh k x ( C sin k y + D cos k y ) Boundary conditions (i) and (ii) require, as before, that D = 0 D = 0 D = 0 and k = n π / a k = n\pi /a k = n π / a , so V ( x , y ) = C cosh ⁡ ( n π x / a ) sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) (3.41) V(x, y) = C \cosh (n \pi x /a )\sin(n \pi y/a) \tagl{3.41} V ( x , y ) = C cosh ( n π x / a ) sin ( n π y / a ) ( 3 . 4 1 ) Because V ( x , y ) V(x, y) V ( x , y ) is even in x, it will automatically meet conditions (iv) if it fits (iii). docs.text: An infinitely long rectangular metal pipe (sides a and b) is grounded, but one end, at x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 , a 'hot' plate is maintained at a specified potential V 0 ( y , z ) V_0(y, z) V 0 ​ ( y , z ) , as indicated in Fig. 3.22. Find the potential inside the pipe. Solution This is genuinely a three-dimensional problem, ∂ 2 V ∂ x 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ y 2 + ∂ 2 V ∂ z 2 = 0 (3.43) \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{x^2}} + \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{y^2}} + \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial{z^2}} = 0 \tagl{3.43} ∂ x 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ y 2 ∂ 2 V ​ + ∂ z 2 ∂ 2 V ​ = 0 ( 3 . 4 3 ) subject to the boundary conditions - (i) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = 0 y = 0 y = 0 - (ii) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when y = a y = a y = a - (iii) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when z = 0 z = 0 z = 0 - (iv) V = 0 V = 0 V = 0 when z = b z = b z = b - (v) V → 0 V \rightarrow 0 V → 0 as x → ∞ x \rightarrow \infty x → ∞ - (vi) V = V 0 ( y , z ) V = V_0(y, z) V = V 0 ​ ( y , z ) whem x = 0 x = 0 x = 0 As always, we look for solutions that are products: V ( x , y , z ) = X ( x ) Y ( y ) Z ( z ) (3.45) V(x, y, z) = X(x)Y(y)Z(z) \tagl{3.45} V ( x , y , z ) = X ( x ) Y ( y ) Z ( z ) ( 3 . 4 5 ) Putting this into ( 3.43 ) \eqref{3.43} ( 3 . 4 3 ) and dividing by V, we find 1 X d 2 X d x 2 + 1 Y d 2 Y d y 2 + 1 Z d 2 Z d z 2 = 0 \frac{1}{X} \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} + \frac{1}{Y} \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} + \frac{1}{Z} \frac{d^2 Z}{dz^2} = 0 X 1 ​ d x 2 d 2 X ​ + Y 1 ​ d y 2 d 2 Y ​ + Z 1 ​ d z 2 d 2 Z ​ = 0 It follows that 1 X d 2 X d x 2 = C 1 , 1 Y d 2 Y d y 2 = C 2 , 1 Z d 2 Z d z 2 = C 3 , with C 1 + C 2 + C 3 = 0 \frac{1}{X} \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} = C_1 , \quad \frac{1}{Y} \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = C_2 , \quad \frac{1}{Z} \frac{d^2 Z}{dz^2} = C_3 , \text{ with } C_1 + C_2 + C_3 = 0 X 1 ​ d x 2 d 2 X ​ = C 1 ​ , Y 1 ​ d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = C 2 ​ , Z 1 ​ d z 2 d 2 Z ​ = C 3 ​ , with C 1 ​ + C 2 ​ + C 3 ​ = 0 Our previous experience in Ex. 3.3 suggests that C 1 C_1 C 1 ​ must be positive, C 2 C_2 C 2 ​ and C 3 C_3 C 3 ​ negative. Setting C 2 = − k 2 C_2 = -k^2 C 2 ​ = − k 2 and C 3 = − l 2 C_3 = -l^2 C 3 ​ = − l 2 , we have C 1 = k 2 + l 2 C_1 = k^2 + l^2 C 1 ​ = k 2 + l 2 , and hence d 2 X d x 2 = ( k 2 + l 2 ) X , d 2 Y d y 2 = − k 2 Y , d 2 Z d z 2 = − l 2 Z (3.46) \frac{d^2 X}{dx^2} = (k^2 + l^2)X, \quad \frac{d^2 Y}{dy^2} = -k^2 Y, \quad \frac{d^2 Z}{dz^2} = -l^2 Z \tagl{3.46} d x 2 d 2 X ​ = ( k 2 + l 2 ) X , d y 2 d 2 Y ​ = − k 2 Y , d z 2 d 2 Z ​ = − l 2 Z ( 3 . 4 6 ) Once again, separation of variables has turned a partial differential equation into ordinary differential equations. The solutions are X ( x ) = A e k 2 + l 2 x + B e − k 2 + l 2 x Y ( y ) = C sin ⁡ k y + D cos ⁡ k y Z ( z ) = E sin ⁡ l z + F cos ⁡ l z \begin{aligned} X(x) & = A e^{\sqrt{k^2 + l^2} x} + B e^{- \sqrt{k^2 + l^2} x} \\ Y(y) & = C \sin ky + D \cos ky \\ Z(z) & = E \sin lz + F \cos lz \end{aligned} X ( x ) Y ( y ) Z ( z ) ​ = A e k 2 + l 2 ​ x + B e − k 2 + l 2 ​ x = C sin k y + D cos k y = E sin l z + F cos l z ​ Boundary condition (v) implies A = 0 A =0 A = 0 , (i) gives D = 0 D = 0 D = 0 , and (iii) yields F = 0 F = 0 F = 0 whereas (ii) and (iv) require that k = n π / a k = n\pi /a k = n π / a and l = m π / b l =m \pi /b l = m π / b , where n and m are positive integers. Combining the remaining constants, we are left with V ( x , y , z ) = C e − π ( n / a ) 2 + ( m / b ) 2 x sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) (3.47) V(x, y, z) = C e^{-\pi \sqrt{(n/a)^2 + (m/b)^2}x} \sin (n \pi y / a) \sin(m \pi z /b) \tagl{3.47} V ( x , y , z ) = C e − π ( n / a ) 2 + ( m / b ) 2 ​ x sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( m π z / b ) ( 3 . 4 7 ) This solution meets all the boundary conditions except (vi). It contains two unspecified integers (n and m), and the most general linear combination is a double sum V ( x , y , z ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ ∑ m = 1 ∞ C e − π ( n / a ) 2 + ( m / b ) 2 x sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) = V 0 ( y , z ) (3.48) V(x, y, z) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} \sum_{m = 1} ^{\infty} C e^{-\pi \sqrt{(n/a)^2 + (m/b)^2}x} \sin (n \pi y / a) \sin(m \pi z /b) = V_0(y, z) \tagl{3.48} V ( x , y , z ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ m = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C e − π ( n / a ) 2 + ( m / b ) 2 ​ x sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( m π z / b ) = V 0 ​ ( y , z ) ( 3 . 4 8 ) We hope to fit the remaining boundary condition, V ( 0 , y , z ) = ∑ n = 1 ∞ ∑ m = 1 ∞ C sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) = V 0 ( y , z ) (3.49) V(0, y, z) = \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} \sum_{m = 1} ^{\infty} C \sin (n \pi y / a) \sin(m \pi z /b) = V_0(y, z) \tagl{3.49} V ( 0 , y , z ) = n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ m = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( m π z / b ) = V 0 ​ ( y , z ) ( 3 . 4 9 ) by appropriate choice of the coefficients C n , m C_{n, m} C n , m ​ . To determine these constants, we multiply by sin ⁡ ( n ′ n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m ′ π z / b ) \sin(n' n \pi y/a) \sin(m' \pi z / b) sin ( n ′ n π y / a ) sin ( m ′ π z / b ) , where n ′ n' n ′ and m ′ m' m ′ are arbitrary positive integers, and integrate ∑ n = 1 ∞ ∑ m = 1 ∞ C n , m ∫ 0 a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( n ′ π y / a ) d y ∫ 0 b sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) sin ⁡ ( m ′ π z / b ) d z = ∫ 0 a ∫ 0 b V 0 ( y , z ) sin ⁡ ( n ′ π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m ′ π z / b ) d y d z \sum_{n=1} ^{\infty} \sum_{m = 1} ^{\infty} C_{n, m} \int_0 ^a \sin (n \pi y/a) \sin(n' \pi y/a) \dd{y} \int_0 ^b \sin(m \pi z/b) \sin (m' \pi z/b) \dd{z} \\ = \int_0 ^a \int_0 ^b V_0(y, z) \sin(n' \pi y/a) \sin(m' \pi z/b) \dd{y} \dd{z} n = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ m = 1 ∑ ∞ ​ C n , m ​ ∫ 0 a ​ sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( n ′ π y / a ) d y ∫ 0 b ​ sin ( m π z / b ) sin ( m ′ π z / b ) d z = ∫ 0 a ​ ∫ 0 b ​ V 0 ​ ( y , z ) sin ( n ′ π y / a ) sin ( m ′ π z / b ) d y d z Quoting ( 3.33 ) \eqref{3.33} ( 3 . 3 3 ) , the left side is ( a b / 4 ) C n ′ , m ′ (ab/4) C_{n', m'} ( a b / 4 ) C n ′ , m ′ ​ , so C n , m = 4 a b ∫ 0 a ∫ 0 b V 0 ( y , z ) sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) d y d z (3.50) C_{n, m} = \frac{4}{ab} \int_0 ^a \int_0 ^b V_0(y, z) \sin (n \pi y/a) \sin(m\pi z/b) \dd{y} \dd{z} \tagl{3.50} C n , m ​ = a b 4 ​ ∫ 0 a ​ ∫ 0 b ​ V 0 ​ ( y , z ) sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( m π z / b ) d y d z ( 3 . 5 0 ) Equation ( 3.48 ) \eqref{3.48} ( 3 . 4 8 ) , with the coefficients given by ( 3.50 ) \eqref{3.50} ( 3 . 5 0 ) , is the solution to our problem. For instance, if the end of the tube is a conductor at constant potential V 0 V_0 V 0 ​ , C n , m = 4 a b ∫ 0 a sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) d y ∫ 0 b sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) d z = { 0 if n or m is even 16 V 0 π 2 n m if n and m are odd (3.51) C_{n, m} = \frac{4}{ab} \int_0 ^a \sin(n \pi y/a) \dd{y} \int_0 ^b \sin(m \pi z/b) \dd{z} \\ = \begin{cases} 0 & \qquad \text{if n or m is even} \\ \frac{16 V_0}{\pi^2 nm} & \qquad \text{if n and m are odd} \end{cases} \tagl{3.51} C n , m ​ = a b 4 ​ ∫ 0 a ​ sin ( n π y / a ) d y ∫ 0 b ​ sin ( m π z / b ) d z = { 0 π 2 n m 1 6 V 0 ​ ​ ​ if n or m is even if n and m are odd ​ ( 3 . 5 1 ) In this case, V ( x , y , z ) = 16 V 0 π 2 ∑ n , m = 1 , 3 , 5 , … ∞ 1 n m e − π ( n / a ) 2 + ( m / b ) 2 x sin ⁡ ( n π y / a ) sin ⁡ ( m π z / b ) (3.52) V(x, y, z) = \frac{16V_0}{\pi^2} \sum_{n,m=1,3,5,\ldots} ^{\infty} \frac{1}{nm} e^{-\pi \sqrt{(n/a)^2 + (m/b)^2}x} \sin(n \pi y/a) \sin(m \pi z/b) \tagl{3.52} V ( x , y , z ) = π 2 1 6 V 0 ​ ​ n , m = 1 , 3 , 5 , … ∑ ∞ ​ n m 1 ​ e − π ( n / a ) 2 + ( m / b ) 2 ​ x sin ( n π y / a ) sin ( m π z / b ) ( 3 . 5 2 ) Notice that successive terms decrease rapidly; a reasonable approximation would be obtained by keeping only the first few.

docs.text: In the examples considered so far, Cartesian coordinates were clearly appropriate, since the boundaries were planes. For round objects, spherical coordinates are more natural. In the spherical system, Laplace's equation reads: 1 r 2 ∂ ∂ r ( r 2 ∂ V ∂ r ) + 1 r 2 sin ⁡ θ ∂ ∂ θ ( sin ⁡ θ ∂ V ∂ θ ) + 1 r 2 sin ⁡ 2 θ ∂ 2 V ∂ ϕ 2 = 0 (3.53) \frac{1}{r^2} \pdv{}{r} \left( r^2 \pdv{V}{r} \right) + \frac{1}{r^2 \sin \theta} \pdv{}{\theta} \left( \sin \theta \pdv{V}{\theta} \right) + \frac{1}{r^2\sin ^2 \theta} \frac{\partial ^2 V}{\partial \phi ^2} = 0 \tagl{3.53} r 2 1 ​ ∂ r ∂ ​ ( r 2 ∂ r ∂ V ​ ) + r 2 sin θ 1 ​ ∂ θ ∂ ​ ( sin θ ∂ θ ∂ V ​ ) + r 2 sin 2 θ 1 ​ ∂ ϕ 2 ∂ 2 V ​ = 0 ( 3 . 5 3 ) I shall assume the problem has azimuthal symmetry , so that V is independent of ϕ \phi ϕ ; In that case, ( 3.53 ) \eqref{3.53} ( 3 . 5 3 ) reduces to ∂ ∂ r ( r 2 ∂ V ∂ r ) + 1 sin ⁡ θ ∂ ∂ θ ( sin ⁡ θ ∂ V ∂ θ ) = 0 (3.54) \pdv{}{r} \left( r^2 \pdv{V}{r} \right) + \frac{1}{\sin \theta} \pdv{}{\theta} \left( \sin \theta \pdv{V}{\theta} \right) = 0 \tagl{3.54} ∂ r ∂ ​ ( r 2 ∂ r ∂ V ​ ) + sin θ 1 ​ ∂ θ ∂ ​ ( sin θ ∂ θ ∂ V ​ ) = 0 ( 3 . 5 4 ) As before, we look for solutions that are products: V ( r , θ ) = R ( r ) Θ ( θ ) (3.55) V(r, \theta) = R(r) \Theta (\theta) \tagl{3.55} V ( r , θ ) = R ( r ) Θ ( θ ) ( 3 . 5 5 ) Putting this into ( 3.54 ) \eqref{3.54} ( 3 . 5 4 ) , and dividing by V , 1 R d   d   r ( r 2 d   R d   r ) + 1 Θ sin ⁡ θ d   d   θ ( sin ⁡ θ d   Θ d   θ ) = 0 (3.56) \frac{1}{R} \dv{}{r} \left( r^2 \dv{R}{r} \right) + \frac{1}{\Theta \sin \theta} \dv{}{\theta} \left( \sin \theta \dv{\Theta}{\theta} \right) = 0 \tagl{3.56} R 1 ​ d r d ​ ( r 2 d r d R ​ ) + Θ sin θ 1 ​ d θ d ​ ( sin θ d θ d Θ ​ ) = 0 ( 3 . 5 6 ) Since the first term depends only on r , and the second only on θ \theta θ , it follows that each must be a constant: 1 R d   d   r ( r 2 d   R d   r ) = l ( l + 1 ) , 1 Θ sin ⁡ θ d   d   θ ( sin ⁡ θ d   Θ d   θ ) = − l ( l + 1 ) (3.57) \frac{1}{R} \dv{}{r} \left( r^2 \dv{R}{r} \right) = l(l+1), \quad \frac{1}{\Theta \sin \theta} \dv{}{\theta} \left( \sin \theta \dv{\Theta}{\theta} \right) = -l(l+1) \tagl{3.57} R 1 ​ d r d ​ ( r 2 d r d R ​ ) = l ( l + 1 ) , Θ sin θ 1 ​ d θ d ​ ( sin θ d θ d Θ ​ ) = − l ( l + 1 ) ( 3 . 5 7 ) Here l ( l + 1 ) l(l+1) l ( l + 1 ) is just a fancy way of writing the separation constant, whose convenience will appear shortly. As always, separation of variables has converted a partial differential equation into ordinary differential equations. The radial equation, d   d   r ( r 2 d   R d   r ) = l ( l + 1 ) R (3.58) \dv{}{r} \left( r^2 \dv{R}{r} \right) = l(l+1)R \tagl{3.58} d r d ​ ( r 2 d r d R ​ ) = l ( l + 1 ) R ( 3 . 5 8 ) has the general solution R ( r ) = A r l + B r l + 1 (3.59) R(r) = A r^l + \frac{B}{r^{l+1}} \tagl{3.59} R ( r ) = A r l + r l + 1 B ​ ( 3 . 5 9 ) as you can easily check; A and B are the two arbitrary constants to be expected in the solution of a second-order differential equation. But the angular equation, d   d   θ ( sin ⁡ θ d   Θ d   θ ) = − l ( l + 1 ) sin ⁡ θ Θ (3.60) \dv{}{\theta} \left( \sin \theta \dv{\Theta}{\theta} \right) = -l(l+1) \sin \theta \Theta \tagl{3.60} d θ d ​ ( sin θ d θ d Θ ​ ) = − l ( l + 1 ) sin θ Θ ( 3 . 6 0 ) is not so simple. The solutions are Legendre polynomials in the variable cos ⁡ θ \cos \theta cos θ : Θ ( θ ) = P l ( cos ⁡ θ ) (3.61) \Theta (\theta ) = P_l (\cos \theta ) \tagl{3.61} Θ ( θ ) = P l ​ ( cos θ ) ( 3 . 6 1 ) P l ( x ) P_l (x) P l ​ ( x ) is most conveniently defined by the Rodrigues formula : P l ( x ) ≡ 1 2 l l ! ( d   d   x ) l ( x 2 − 1 ) l (3.62) P_l(x) \equiv \frac{1}{2^l l!}\left( \dv{}{x} \right)^l (x^2 - 1)^l \tagl{3.62} P l ​ ( x ) ≡ 2 l l ! 1 ​ ( d x d ​ ) l ( x 2 − 1 ) l ( 3 . 6 2 ) The first few Legendre polynomials are listed: Legendre Polynomials P 0 P_0 P 0 ​ - P 5 P_5 P 5 ​ P 0 ( x ) = 1 P 1 ( x ) = x P 2 ( x ) = ( 3 x 2 − 1 ) / 2 P 3 ( x ) = ( 5 x 3 − 3 x ) / 2 P 4 ( x ) = ( 35 x 4 − 30 x 2 + 3 ) / 8 P 5 ( x ) = ( 63 x 5 − 70 x 3 + 15 x ) / 8 \begin{aligned} P_0(x) & = 1 \\ P_1(x) & = x \\ P_2(x) & = (3x^2 - 1)/2 \\ P_3(x) & = (5x^3 - 3x)/2 \\ P_4(x) & = (35x^4 - 30x^2 + 3)/8 \\ P_5(x) & = (63x^5 - 70x^3 + 15x)/8 \end{aligned} P 0 ​ ( x ) P 1 ​ ( x ) P 2 ​ ( x ) P 3 ​ ( x ) P 4 ​ ( x ) P 5 ​ ( x ) ​ = 1 = x = ( 3 x 2 − 1 ) / 2 = ( 5 x 3 − 3 x ) / 2 = ( 3 5 x 4 − 3 0 x 2 + 3 ) / 8 = ( 6 3 x 5 − 7 0 x 3 + 1 5 x ) / 8 ​ Notice that P l ( x ) P_l(x) P l ​ ( x ) is (as the name suggests) an _l_th-order polynomial in x; it contains only even powers if l is even, and only odd powers if l is odd. The factor in front ( 1 / 2 l l ! (1/2^l l! ( 1 / 2 l l ! was chosen in order that P l ( 1 ) = 1 (3.63) P_l(1) = 1 \tagl{3.63} P l ​ ( 1 ) = 1 ( 3 . 6 3 ) The Rodrigues formula obviously only works for nonnegative integer values of l. Moreover, it provides us with only one solution. But ( 3.60 ) \eqref{3.60} ( 3 . 6 0 ) is second-order, and it should possess two independent solutions for every value of l . It turns out that these "other solutions" blow up at θ = 0 \theta = 0 θ = 0 and/or θ = π \theta = \pi θ = π , and are therefore unacceptable on physical grounds. For instance, the second solution for l = 0 l=0 l = 0 is Θ ( θ ) = ln ⁡ ( tan ⁡ θ 2 ) (3.64) \Theta(\theta) = \ln \left( \tan \frac{\theta}{2} \right) \tagl{3.64} Θ ( θ ) = ln ( tan 2 θ ​ ) ( 3 . 6 4 ) You might want to check for yourself that this satisfies ( 3.60 ) \eqref{3.60} ( 3 . 6 0 ) . In the case of azimuthal symmetry, then, the most general separable solution to Laplace's equation, consistent with minimal physical requirements, is V ( r , θ ) = ( A r l + B r l + 1 ) P l ( cos ⁡ θ ) V(r, \theta) = \left( A r^l + \frac{B}{r^{l+1}} \right) P_l(\cos \theta) V ( r , θ ) = ( A r l + r l + 1 B ​ ) P l ​ ( cos θ ) (There was no need to include an overall constant in ( 3.61 ) \eqref{3.61} ( 3 . 6 1 ) because it can be absorbed into A and B at this stage.) As before, separation of variables yields an infinite set of solutions, one for each l . The general solution is the linear combination of separable solutions: V ( r , θ ) = ∑ l = 0 ∞ ( A r l + B r l + 1 ) P l ( cos ⁡ θ ) (3.65) V(r, \theta) = \sum_{l=0} ^{\infty} \left( A r^l + \frac{B}{r^{l+1}} \right) P_l(\cos \theta) \tagl{3.65} V ( r , θ ) = l = 0 ∑ ∞ ​ ( A r l + r l + 1 B ​ ) P l ​ ( cos θ ) ( 3 . 6 5 ) The following examples illustrate the power of this important result.
docs.title: 3.3.2: Spherical Coordinates

docs.text: The potential V 0 ( θ ) V_0(\theta) V 0 ​ ( θ ) is specified on the surface of a hollow sphere, of radius R . Find the potential inside the sphere. Solution In this case, B l = 0 B_l = 0 B l ​ = 0 for all l , otherwise the potential would blow up at the origin. Thus, V ( r , θ ) = ∑ l = 0 ∞ A l r l P l ( cos ⁡ θ ) (3.66) V(r, \theta) = \sum_{l = 0} ^{\infty} A_l r^l P_l(\cos \theta) \tagl{3.66} V ( r , θ ) = l = 0 ∑ ∞ ​ A l ​ r l P l ​ ( cos θ ) ( 3 . 6 6 ) At r = R r = R r = R this must match the specified function V 0 ( θ ) V_0(\theta) V 0 ​ ( θ ) : V ( R , θ ) = ∑ l = 0 ∞ A l R l P l ( cos ⁡ θ ) = V 0 ( θ ) (3.67) V(R, \theta) = \sum_{l=0}^\infty A_l R^l P_l(\cos \theta) = V_0(\theta) \tagl{3.67} V ( R , θ ) = l = 0 ∑ ∞ ​ A l ​ R l P l ​ ( cos θ ) = V 0 ​ ( θ ) ( 3 . 6 7 ) Can this equation be satisfied, for an appropriate choice of coefficients A l A_l A l ​ ? Yes: The Legendre polynomials (like the sines) constitute a complete set of functions, on the interval − 1 ≤ x ≤ 1 ( 0 ≤ θ ≤ π ) -1 \leq x \leq 1 (0 \leq \theta \leq \pi) − 1 ≤ x ≤ 1 ( 0 ≤ θ ≤ π ) . docs.text: .katex img { display: block; position: absolute; width: 100%; height: inherit; } 3.4: Multipole Expansion 3.4.1: Approximate Potentials at Large Distances If you are very far away from a localized charge distribution, it "looks" like a point charge, and the potential is - to good approximation - ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ) Q / r (1/4 \pi \epsilon_0) Q/r ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ​ ) Q / r , where Q Q Q is the total charge. We have often used this as a check on formulas for V . But what if Q Q Q is zero? You might reply that the potential is then approximately zero, and of course, you're right in a sense (indeed, the potential at large r is pretty small even if Q is not zero). But we're looking for something a bit more informative than that. Notice, however, that this is only the approximate potential of the physical dipole - evidently there are higher multipole contributions. By the same token, at a fixed r r r the dipole approximation improves as you shrink the separation distance d d d . Unfortunately you then lose the dipole term too, unless you simultaneously arrange for q to go to infinity! A physical dipole becomes a pure dipole, then, in the rather artificial limit d → 0. q → ∞ d \rightarrow 0. q \rightarrow \infty d → 0 . q → ∞ , with the product q d = p qd = p q d = p held fixed. When someone uses the word "dipole," you can't always tell whether they mean a physical dipole (with finite separation between the charges) or an ideal dipole. If in doubt, assume that d is small enough that you can safely apply ( 3.99 ) \eqref{3.99} ( 3 . 9 9 ) . Dipole moments are vectors , and they add accordingly: if you have two dipoles p 1 \vec{p_1} p 1 ​ and p 2 \vec{p_2} p 2 ​ , the total dipole moment is p 1 + p 2 \vec{p_1} + \vec{p_2} p 1 ​ + p 2 ​ . For instance, with four charges at the corners of a square, as shown in Fig. 3.30, the net dipole moment is zero. You can see this by combining the charges in pairs or by adding up the four contributions individually using ( 3.100 ) \eqref{3.100} ( 3 . 1 0 0 ) . This is a quadrupole , as I indicated earlier, and its potential is dominated by the quadrupole term in the multipole expansion. 3.4.3: Origin of Coordinates in Multipole Expansions I mentioned earlier that a point charge at the origin constitutes a "pure" monopole. If it is not at the origin, it's no longer a pure monopole. For instance, the charge in Fig. 3.32 has a dipole moment p = q d y ^ \vec{p} = q d \vu{y} p = q d y ^ ​ , and a corresponding dipole term in its potential. The multipole expansion is, remember, a series in inverse powers of r (the distance to the origin), and when we expand 1 / γ 1/\gr 1 / γ , we get all powers, not just the first. So moving the origin (or, what amounts to the same thing, moving the charge) can radically alter a multipole expansion. The monopole moment Q Q Q does not change, since the total charge is obviously independent of the coordinate system. (In Fig. 3.32, the monopole term was unaffected when we moved q away from the origin - it's just that it was no longer the whole story: a dipole term - and for that matter all higher poles - appeared as well.) Ordinarily, the dipole moment does change when you shift the origin, but there is an important exception: If the total charge is zero, then the dipole moment is independent of the choice of origin. For suppose we displace the origin by an amount a \vec{a} a (Fig. 3.33). So if someone asks for the dipole moment in Fig 3.34(a), you can answer with confidence " q d q \vec{d} q d ," but if you're asked for the dipole moment in Fig 3.34(b), the appropriate response would be "With respect to what origin?" 3.4.4: The Electric Field of a Dipole So far we have only worked with potentials . Now I would like to calculate the electric field of a (perfect) dipole. Quadrupole fields go like 1 / r 4 1/r^4 1 / r 4 , octopole like 1 / r 5 1/r^5 1 / r 5 , and so on. (This merely reflects how the respective potentials fall off - the gradient introduces another factor of 1 / r 1/r 1 / r ). docs.text: If you are very far away from a localized charge distribution, it "looks" like a point charge, and the potential is - to good approximation - ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ) Q / r (1/4 \pi \epsilon_0) Q/r ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ​ ) Q / r , where Q Q Q is the total charge. We have often used this as a check on formulas for V . But what if Q Q Q is zero? You might reply that the potential is then approximately zero, and of course, you're right in a sense (indeed, the potential at large r is pretty small even if Q is not zero). But we're looking for something a bit more informative than that.

docs.text: I mentioned earlier that a point charge at the origin constitutes a "pure" monopole. If it is not at the origin, it's no longer a pure monopole. For instance, the charge in Fig. 3.32 has a dipole moment p = q d y ^ \vec{p} = q d \vu{y} p = q d y ^ ​ , and a corresponding dipole term in its potential. The monopole potential ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ) q / r (1/4 \pi \epsilon_0) q/r ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ​ ) q / r is not quite correct for this configuration; rather, the exact potential is ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ) q / γ (1/4 \pi \epsilon_0) q/\gr ( 1 / 4 π ϵ 0 ​ ) q / γ . The multipole expansion is, remember, a series in inverse powers of r (the distance to the origin), and when we expand 1 / γ 1/\gr 1 / γ , we get all powers, not just the first. So moving the origin (or, what amounts to the same thing, moving the charge) can radically alter a multipole expansion. The monopole moment Q Q Q does not change, since the total charge is obviously independent of the coordinate system. (In Fig. 3.32, the monopole term was unaffected when we moved q away from the origin - it's just that it was no longer the whole story: a dipole term - and for that matter all higher poles - appeared as well.) Ordinarily, the dipole moment does change when you shift the origin, but there is an important exception: If the total charge is zero, then the dipole moment is independent of the choice of origin.
